results.description:
Please ask at the Host Stand for book club. Their Tuesday special is 55 cent bites. Here is their website for more details - http://sharpedgebeer.com/beer-emporium-2

Well, it seems as though the Sharp Edge may be our new spot! They were really great to us last night. There's ample parking, a good menu, and lots of space. So well be there again in June.

We chose Tempting Fate by Jane Green - from Amazon.com:

Gabby and Elliott have been happily married for eighteen years. They have two teenaged daughters. They have built a life together. Forty-three year old Gabby is the last person to have an affair. She can't relate to the way her friends desperately try to cling to the beauty and allure of their younger years…And yet, she too knows her youth is quickly slipping away. She could never imagine how good it would feel to have a handsome younger man show interest in her--until the night it happens. Matt makes Gabby feel sparkling, fascinating,alive--something she hasn't felt in years. What begins as a long-distance friendship soon develops into an emotional affair as Gabby discovers her limits and boundaries are not where she expects them to be. Intoxicated, Gabby has no choice but to step ever deeper into the allure of attraction and attention, never foreseeing the life-changing consequences that lie ahead. If she makes one wrong move she could lose everything--and find out what really matters most. 
A heartfelt and complex story, Tempting Fate will have readers gripped until they reach the very last page, and thinking about the characters long after they put the book down.

Hope to see you there!
results.why: We love to read, drink wine and talk about books!

results.description:
The jazz event of the year! Hosted by actress and singer Gloria Reuben, and kicking off the Pittsburgh Jazz Live International Festival, with music made famous by legendary Pittsburghers. This star-studded concert features Roger Humphries, David Budway, Sean Jones and others.

After intermission, Ramsey Lewis and Kurt Elling will join the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra to explore the music of Billy Strayhorn, George Benson, Henry Mancini and others. Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra bassist, Jeff Grubbs, will perform the Ray Brown Suite with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra. Throughout it all, watch for clips from the new PBS documentary film celebrating the Legacy of Jazz in Pittsburgh.

Tickets are in the range of $25-$80 depending on how close you'd like to sit to the stage although some discount options are available (see below for details).

There is also a Gala Option which includes a pre-show reception beginning at 6 PM with appearances by Pittsburgh Jazz Legends, live music by the COL Jazz Band, and delicious hors d'doueuvres. For Gala/Concert packages which begin at 6 PM (please note that the Gala/Concert Option is $250/each), please visit www.mcgjazz.org or call[masked]

Check out this great article about the concert http://triblive.com/aande/music/8457109-74/jazz-pittsburgh-music#axzz3cmAdb6Q7

Concert Program


The concert begins at 8 PM with a jazz ensemble featuring MCG Jazz Pittsburgh Jazz Legend Roger Humphries along with David Budway on piano, Joel Frahm on saxophone, Jay Ashby on trombone, Dwayne Dolphin on bass and Sean Jones on trumpet. The second half of the concert features the Pittsburgh Symphony, under the baton of Jeff Tyzik, performing newly arranged pieces specifically for NEA Jazz Master Ramsey Lewis and Grammy Award-winning vocalist Kurt Elling.  Pittsburgh Symphony bassist Jeff Grubbs will be the featured soloist on Ray Brown’s orchestral work, “Afterthoughts.” David Budway and Sean Jones will also perform selections with the Pittsburgh Symphony. Immediately following the concert, a CD signing with several featured artists will be held in the Heinz Hall lobby.

Throughout it all, watch for clips from the new PBS documentary film celebrating the legacy of jazz in Pittsburgh.

For more information, please visit http://www.pittsburghsymphony.org/production/44470/the-pittsburgh-jazz-celebration

FOR TICKETS & Discount Options - Concert Only

1) Because of the general desire for people that would like to sit together, one approach is to buy at the door so we'll have a good feel of attendance as compared to buying all the tickets in advance and hoping everyone can make the show. 

Please be at the Heinz Hall Box Office at 7:30 PM for introductions, buying tickets together, etc. before it gets too busy.

We'll also monitor advance ticket sales to let everyone know if there is a chance the concert might sell out -- but as of know, we expect tickets to be available at the door.

We expect many people may wish to buy $25 tickets at the door, but it is certainly fine if smaller groups of people would like to buy more expensive tickets closer to the stage.

2) Discount Option -- This concert is also offered through the Goldstar discount ticketing company where people can get 50% off advance tickets plus $5-$6 handling fee (per ticket) which for this particular concert equates to a total of $27-$35 per ticket depending on how close you'd like to sit to the stage as these discount seats are located in Orchestra Floor, Grand Tier, and Family Circle (where regular ticket prices are $43-$58). Thus, these Goldstar discount seats will be closer to the stage than buying $25 regular tickets at the door (for upper balcony/Gallery) as described in Option #1 above. So if anyone wants to pick out their own seats and get a discount, please feel free to consider this option as you could also just meet the rest of the Meetup group (doing Option #1 above) in the lobby before the show or during intermission. For more info or to order advance tickets via Goldstar, please visit http://www.goldstar.com/events/pittsburgh-pa/the-pittsburgh-jazz-celebration-tickets

Please note that these discounts are not unlimited -- in other words, there is a limit on how many 50% off tickets Goldstar has access to for each show.

In case you're wondering, here is a listing of about 20 upcoming shows all over the Pittsburgh region where Goldstar has access to 50% discount tickets http://www.goldstar.com/pittsburgh/events/?page=3&mode=infinite In addition, Goldstar operates in many other cities. While Goldstar is certainly not a substitute for more traditional savings and benefits through the usual subscriptions or other discount offers (including what we can sometimes arrange for ourselves via Meetup), it is a relatively new option for Pittsburgh. 

FYI, here is a link with some background and FAQ about Goldstar, including links to articles about them from the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Forbes, etc.  http://www.goldstar.com/company

Please note that Goldstar is free to join.

3) Regular Tickets -- Others are certainly welcome to arrange for their own tickets.  This can be done by visiting or calling the Heinz Hall Box Office [masked]), visiting or calling the Theater Square Box Office [masked]) or going online http://www.pittsburghsymphony.org/production/44470/the-pittsburgh-jazz-celebration

As always, it is also fine if you'd like to attend this concert on your own with family/friends instead.

For more information and ticket availability about this concert at Heinz Hall, please visit http://www.pittsburghsymphony.org/production/44470/the-pittsburgh-jazz-celebration

For more information about the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra PSO and other concerts coming up at Heinz Hall, please visit http://www.pittsburghsymphony.org/pso_home

Parking Here is the ParkPGH website with real-time info on downtown parking garage availability http://parkpgh.org where you can also download apps, get garage availability via text messaging, etc. You can also call[masked]-8980.

Stay tuned for updates!
results.how_to_find_us: Please meet inside Heinz Hall Box Office at 7:30 PM prior to 8 PM concert. Meeting early is especially important for those that wish to buy at the door and sit together

results.description:
Don't miss this opportunity to learn from an expert all the first-aid supplies you'll need for your next outdoor adventure. We'll start by focusing on the five basic variables to consider when building a first-aid kit: group size, trip length and distance, potential injuries and illnesses, specific medical conditions and your own medical knowledge and skills. Plus, we'll discuss the benefits of assemble-it-yourself first-aid kits vs. pre-assembled kits. You'll also participate in a hands-on, small-group discussion of the contents needed for a first-aid kit based on three different outing scenarios. You'll assess the needs of each kit based on the first three basic variables outlined earlier in the clinic. Afterwards, the whole group will come together to discuss what first-aid materials would be needed for each scenario. Our experts will also briefly explain the purpose for each item in the kit. They also discuss where it should be placed, so it can be quickly located during stressful emergency situations. Please note: This is not a first-aid certification class. Proper first-aid training is very important for knowing what to do in emergency situations. You should only attempt first aid when you feel comfortable giving it.

Thank you for your interest in our free "First Aid Kit Clinic." L.L.Bean has a new centralized reservation system. To guarantee your space, you must first confirm your reservation on our new centralized reservation system, and if appropriate, fill out a participant agreement. Please visit www.llbean.com/pittsburgh (on a computer and not mobile device), find this event on the "Event Calendar", and register. We look forward to seeing you!


Learn the skills for a lifetime of adventure:
  • L.L.Bean Outdoor Discovery Schools  LLBean.com/Adventure
</a>

Need help preparing for your next adventure? Visit <a href="http://www.llbean.com/llb/shop/1000001727">L.L.Bean Store at Ross Park Mall and ask to speak with an Outdoor Product Specialist. L.L.Bean will fit you with the right clothing and gear for all of life's adventures.

L.L.Bean Store at Ross Park Mall
1000 Ross Park Mall Drive
Pittsburgh, PA  15237
Twitter
L.L.Bean Pittsburgh Outdoor Adventure Club on Meetup
L.L.Bean Outdoor Discovery School
<a href="http://llbean.com/adventure"></a>

results.name: Free In-Store Clinic - First Aid Kit

Join us for some German conversation at our biweekly Stammtisch in Shadyside! Stammtisch is a casual, drop-in atmosphere, with plenty of opportunities to meet and talk with others. We have all levels of proficiency, from native speakers to those just starting to learn – we’re a friendly bunch and would love to have you join us! 


There are currently two recurring Stammtisches - one on Wednesdays in Shadyside and one in the South Hills on Saturdays, both held biweekly, at the same time and place. If you can't make it this time, keep an eye open for the next one!

results.description:
Regular season weekly Wednesday Start and Stop Clinic and organized street skates in Shadyside.

 

"FREE" Lessons start at 6:30 pm & the street skates start at 7:00 pm. If you need loaner skates, helmet, wrist guards for lessons please call [masked]) at least 2 days in advance or email at: [masked]

Two (2) street skates available:

Beginners Skate (7:15pm) is for those new to skating and having learned some of the basic skating and braking skills. Lasts about 45 minutes. Skate is on fairly level back streets of Shadyside with minimal traffic. This is a patrolled skate.

Advanced Beginners Skate (7:00pm) for those who can brake and skate with confidence and are ready to improve their skills. Ability to skate small hills and some street traffic. Skate lasts from about 1 to 1  1/2 hours. Skate route is generally from Shadyside to Oakland, Pitt, CMU and surrounding areas. This is a patrolled skate.

Helmets and wrist guards required as a minimum on all skates.

Occasional post skate tailgate gathering or walk to local eateries after the skate.

Note: All skates are weather permitting. If the streets are dry we should be skating!

Lessons are conducted by the National Skate Patrol.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet on a paved school yard, off street, fenced school yard area between Filbert and Ivy Streets along Ellsworth Ave. in Shadyside.
results.name: TRIC / NSP - Wednesday Beginners Skates & FREE Skate Lessons

Come at 6:45 pm to tune-up and talk. We play from 7 to 9 pm, starting with the playlist below, followed by requests. No experience required! All levels are welcome, from beginners to professionals. If you don't know the chords... just sing louder.  Please bring your own folding chair to Biddle's so that their regular customers have seats. Here is a photo of Biddle's deck.


Biddle's invites Food Trucks every Wednesday.  Here is a schedule for 2015. Arrive early if you want to order from the Food Trucks as the lines are always long and slow.  Please purchase your drinks from Biddle's - they treat us well and we should return the favor.

results.description:
We agreed that Bartram House Bakery was a good place to meet so we will be back there in June.  If the weather is nice, we'll figure out a way to pull the tables together outside.  

Our book choice for June is Summer Rental by Mary Kay Andrews, an author our group is quickly growing to love.  Here's some info about the book:

Ellis, Julia, and Dorie. Best friends since Catholic grade school, they now find themselves in their mid-thirties, at the crossroads of life and love. Ellis, recently fired from her job, begins to question the choices she's made over the past decade. Julia has a man who loves her and is offering her the world, but she can no longer hide her deepest insecurities. And Dorie has just been shockingly betrayed by the man she loved and trusted the most. Can a one-month getaway to North Carolina's Outer Banks help make things right?
Sometimes the tide just pulls you in the right direction…

The landlord of the ladies' beach house is Ty Bazemore, who's hanging on to the property by a thread--even as he finds himself spiraling into a deep attraction with Ellis. Then there's Maryn Shackleford, a stranger who arrives on the scene in search of a good hiding place and a new identity. Can Ellis, Julia, and Dorie provide what Maryn is looking for? Five people on a journey that will uncover their secrets and point them on the path to renewal and forgiveness. One summer rental that might be what each of them has needed all along…


Bring some book suggestions for July.  If we have enough choices, we'll pick for August too.

results.description:
OUT OF THIS FURNACE ... Returns!

Based on Thomas Bell’s famous story of immigrant families living and working in the steel mills of Pittsburgh.

The triumphantly human story of heart sweat and steel. Your Story.

Three generations of the Kracha/Dobrecjak clan struggle to build a life in the shadow of Carnegie’s first mill. A dramatic adaptation of Thomas Bell’s intimate tale of immigrants, labor and the rise of unions in Braddock, PA.

*In a new adaptation*

Directed by Lisa Ann Goldsmith

June 4th - 27nd, 2015

About the Play

When Unseam'd originally premiered "Out of This Furnace" in 2008 at the former Open Stage Theatre (located in the Strip District), it quickly became one of the hottest tickets in town with many sold out performances.  Audiences loved the play which attracted many steel workers and their families along with others with personal connections to the steel mills as well as many audience members that had read Thomas Bell's iconic novel.  The 2008 production had a great cast, set, and soundscape making audiences feel the sounds inside the mills.  The 2008 play was adapted for the stage by Andy Wolk (based on Thomas Bell's iconic novel) and directed by Marci Woodruff. 

Due to popular demand, the play was restaged by Unseam'd in 2011 at a different location, which was the Studio Theatre in Oakland. This production was also directed by Marci Woodruff but had a different cast. The 2011 production also had a very successful run in terms of audience response.

And now, this 2015 production will be a new adaption directed by Lisa Ann Goldsmith with a new cast featuring Charles Beikert, Lea DiMarchi, Kate Falk, Matthew Mazurowski, Julia Netzer, Max Pavel, Charles David Richards, Jennifer Tober, Tammy Tsai, and Mark Warchol

Performances during June 4 - 27, 2015


Studio Theatre in the Cathedral of Learning

4200 Fifth Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213

GENERAL ADMISSION: $27 Advance ($30 at the door)
STUDENTS: $15 Advance ($18 at the door)
SENIORS: $22 Advanced ($25 at the door)
GROUP (6+): 10% Discount (Advanced Sales Only)

SHOWTIMES: Wednesday through Saturday @ 7:30 pm, Sundays @ 4:00 pm 

Post-show discussions with director and cast on Wednesday, June 10 & 17

MEETUP Ticket Discount

If anyone is interested in going to the June 4th - 6th shows, you can order advance tickets at the special price of $22 by entering MEETUP in the promo code box when checking out online. This code can only be used on general admission tickets for the June 4th - 6th shows. 

For all of the other performance dates June 7-27, a 10% off discount will be available by entering MEETUP10 in the promo box.

For advance tickets, please go online to the Unseam'd website http://unseamd.com/box-office/ or ShowClix website http://www.showclix.com/search/out%20of%20this%20furnace to see all of the performance dates and then you can enter either the promo code MEETUP for $22 online tickets for the June 4-6 performances or MEETUP10 code for 10% off online tickets for all of the other performances June 7-27.

You can also call ShowClix at[masked]-4253.

For more information about Unseam'd Shakespeare, please visit http://unseamd.com/

We'll also try to arrange some alternate dates for Meetup groups to check out this powerful thought-provoking play. So please post some comments below if you'd like to suggest some alternate performance dates for the group to consider. 

But we'll select Wednesday, June 17 as one of the Meetup group dates since there will be a post-show discussion with the director and cast. I'm sure there will be some interesting questions and insights.


We're also planning a Meetup for the Friday, June 26 performance for those that may be interested. For more information or to RSVP for June 26 instead, please visit http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/events/223106379/

As always, it is also fine if people would like to go on their own with family/friends for a truly memorable evening.

Stay tuned for updates!

About the Novel Out of This Furnace (from Wikipedia)

Out of This Furnace is a historical novel and the best-known work of the American writer Thomas Bell. The novel is set in Braddock, Pennsylvania, a steel town just east of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania along the Monongahela River. It was first published in 1941 by Little, Brown and Company. Based upon Bell's own family of Rusyn and Slovak immigrants, the story follows three generations of a family, starting with their migration in 1881 from Austria-Hungary to the United States, and finishing with World War II. The novel focuses on the steelworkers' attempt to unionize from 1889, the first Homestead strike through the big Homestead Steel Strike of 1892, the Great Steel Strike of 1919 right after World War I, and the events of the 1930s (<a>Labor Organizing</a>). A common connection of struggle, poverty, and entire need of the characters of forces out of their control come together to tell a story of a tragic depiction of a truly troubled group of people. Shared with unbearable financial adversity, the Slovaks nicknamed "Hunkies" were also exposed to discrimination by other "Americans." The novel's title refers to the central role of the steel mill in the family's life and in the history of the Pittsburgh region.

Long out of print, the novel was rediscovered in the 1970s by David P. Demarest, a professor of English at Carnegie Mellon University, who convinced director Frederick A. Hetzel at the University of Pittsburgh Press to reissue it in 1976. The book quickly became a regional bestseller. By the 1980s, however, it found an even larger readership on American college campuses. Out of This Furnace is regularly used as required reading in universities to introduce students to the history of immigration, industrialization, and the rise of trade unionism, as well as to the genre of the American working class novel.

Once every four months.  I ask people to come with ideas for our next FOUR Months of  Happy Hours.  (June-Sept).  We meet, catch a bite to eat, Bullshit and then figure out where we are setting up the next four happy hours.

The only requirements of the Happy Hour:

1.  Place needs to be Popular or have a hook that grabs people to go to the Happy Hour (Outdoor Deck/Patio, Band, Amazing Food, Dancing/DJ or something else)

2.  Room enough for 100 people over and above their normal crowd.  The current monthly Happy Hours are getting[masked] people.

Other than that anything goes.  Happy Hour can be Thurs-Sat picked out by the Point Person, The time frame is 3 hours, which gives people opportunities to do other things afterwards if they want. 

We'll meet at the BAR at Mad Mex Robinson at 7:30pm, get a table to eat and then figure out which places we want to have a Happy Hour.  And then we decide where.

There will be a point person who contacts the management, gets the specials and the permission to do this.

Frank gets the word out via 6-8 meetup group plus a facebook event.  The Facebook events are for everyone in the committee to invite their friends to the Happy Hour!

Hi All,

We're meeting at 6:00 at the tennis court of Schenley  park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

I've been to this a couple of times it's fun... Frank the Admin


The Pittsburgh Banjo Club is a non-profit organization made up of men and women from all walks of life, with a common goal - the encouragement and preservation of the banjo, America’s Native Instrument. Founded on December 15, 1988, by Frank Rossi, the Pittsburgh Banjo Club is dedicated to keeping the music of the Golden Age of the Banjo alive [masked]). Frank Rossi was inducted into the National Four-String Banjo Hall of Fame on May 24, 2001. The Banjo Hall of Fame is located at the American Banjo Museum in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.

The Pittsburgh Banjo Club includes banjos, trumpets, tubas, and bass. Dressed in bright, colorful uniforms, the Pittsburgh Banjo Club makes a striking appearance while playing the happiest music in the world, putting a smile on your face, a tap in your toe and a song in your heart! The happiest sound in the world is a banjo and the Pittsburgh Banjo Club provides miles of smiles!

The Pittsburgh Banjo Club program consists of sing-alongs, vocals, banjo solos, music from the ’20s and ’30s, polkas and Dixieland.

results.description:
WINE TASTING CRUISE - A Spectacular Evening of Wine, Food & Fun!

Please join us for a special evening aboard the Gateway Clipper Empress  -- where guests will be pampered with a special menu perfectly paired with hand-picked wines from Spain.

This is one evening you won't want to miss! Where guests experience sightseeing as well as the relaxing beauty of the Three Rivers -- with the transitions from daylight, twilight, and evening under the stars.  

With so many people in the Meetup, sometimes it can be challenge meeting/mingling, especially for relatively new members when attending other events at busy art galleries, outdoor festivals, and performances at large venues such as the Benedum. So perhaps a series of fun activities that bring lots of people together would also help with introductions and spotting other members at future events.

Looking for a unique Pittsburgh Activity? Come aboard for an evening that features dinner, wine and a river cruise on the Three Rivers!

Enjoy a fabulous menu that compliments the three featured wines chosen by wine experts. This river cruise also features boarding hors d’ouevres and a seated tasting plate dinner.

Six dates to choose!  Six regions of wine! An informative and fun evening  for “oenophiles” of every level! Cheers!

     Board: 5:30 pm

     Sail: 6:30 – 9:00 pm

Check out the fantastic menu for the Spanish wine cruise

     HORS D'OEUVRES  

Scallop Mac & Cheese Morsels, Tomato Chutney
       General Tso's Boneless Chicken Spears
       Domestic Cheese Assortment, Bread, Crackers and Grapes
       Bouquet of Raw Vegetables with Herb Buttermilk Dressing

       Wine Selection -- Latue Airen 2013, La Mancha, Spain
   

      MAIN ENTREE  --   Choice of one below

        Bordeauz Braised Boneless Short Ribs
        Boursin Cheese Mashed Potatoes
        Bourgeon Stewed Vegetables
        Crispy Shallot and Braising Jus

                              OR

Roast Pierre Breast of Chicken
       Lacinato Kale, Pearl Pasta Frivaldi, Roasted Garlic and Rosemary Brodo

        Two Wines Served with Entree -- Bodegas Paniza Sinello Viejas Vinas Garnacha 2013, Cainena, Spain and Pares Balta Mas Petit 2013 (Cab/Grenache Blend), Penedes, Spain


      DESSERT

Fudge Brownies, Lemon Squares and Cookies
       Seasonal Fresh Fruit Arrangement

TICKETS

To order $57.16 tickets in advance (which includes all taxes and service charge), please call [masked] (then press "1" for reservations) --- and then you'll be asked which of the two above entrees you prefer. When you order your tickets, please mention the reservation code "224441" if you (and any guests) would like to be seated with the group.

As always, it is also fine if you would like to enjoy this cruise on your own with family/friends.

Because everyone has different commuting times to the city, this approach will be a little easier so you won't be in as much of a rush -- as long as you can board before the ship leaves the dock at 6:30 PM.

So while some people may decide to arrive early and have a bit more time to mingle and check out the ship -- it is not necessary.  You'll still have a seat with the Meetup group whether you decide to arrive at 5:30-6:15 PM or board the ship before it leaves the dock at 6:30 PM.

The seating configuration is typically 8 people per table, so it would be great if we had several tables next to each other for those that would like to sit together.

This wine cruise is expected to sell out in advance. We'll try to monitor situation and let people know so they can finalize their tickets, mostly likely in early/mid-June.

FYI, here is the schedule for other Wine Tasting Cruises aboard the Gateway Clipper

    June 18, 2015 at 6:30 PM -- WINE TASTING SPAIN More info


    July 23, 2015 at 6:30 PM -- WINE TASTING WHITE WINE More info


    August 20, 2015 at 6:30 PM -- WINE TASTING CHILEAN More info


    September 24, 2015 at 6:30 PM -- WINE TASTING RUSTIC ITALIAN More info


    October 15, 2015 at 6:30 PM  -- WINE TASTING RED WINE More info


This cruise will no doubt provide guests an even deeper appreciation of how the city has awakened with so many recreational opportunities along the Three Rivers (walking trails, river kayaking, boating/fishing) recent developments with the restoration of Point State Park, preservation of nearby historic buildings, as well as new buildings enhancing Pittsburgh's modern skyline -- and more fully experience how the city and rivers really stand out in the transition from daylight, twilight, and evening under the stars. 

We may never see the city the same way after experiencing the cruise!

To check out the upcoming schedule for other Gateway Clipper wine cruises, please visit http://www.gatewayclipper.com/public-cruises/dining/wine-tasting-2/

For more information about the Gateway Clipper, please visit http://www.gatewayclipper.com/

Don't forget to bring your camera!

Stay tuned for updates!

results.description:
We had 10 people show up for game 1 and everyone had a great time (5 of the 10 were first time players).  Come join us for this unique but fun game!

This game got quite popular last year and was requested as our Meetup of the week for 7 straight weeks.  I'd love to find a flatter field to play it on but Flagstaff Hill will have to do for now.  

The name of the game is Big Ball. I created this game during my junior year at IUP. The best way to describe the game is that it's a mix between Soccer and Ultimate Frisbee but we use a ball that's about 45" in diameter. We played it every week for 2 years on the practice soccer field. There is no physical contact with other players permitted but you can use the ball however you want. Any part of your body can touch the ball and there's no height limit on the goals. Also, NO CLEATS OR SPIKES ALLOWED!


To see a video of this game in action from 3 years ago, check it out here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=deBQzfRsBg0

We will be playing this game at Flagstaff Hill across from Phipps Conservatory.

Here are some more details & rules.

Field size we need is about 60 - 70 yards based on how many players we get (best games are at least 7 vs 7)

There are 3 lines that matter in the game...the goal line on each side and the line at the center of the field. There are no out of bounds lines on the sides of the field.

Players can dribble, roll, kick, throw or carry the ball for 3 steps

The goals are as wide as a field goal post in football and there is no height limit on the goal. The game relies heavily on defense. There are also no regulations for goalies or a goalie box. This means your goalie can play mid field if he wants or you can even have 3 goalies...they can even piggyback on each other to be "taller" if they want. You just lose those additional players in the field

Both teams start the game and after each goal at mid-field. The team that wins the coin toss or just got scored on start with the ball. As soon as anything crosses mid-field (the ball OR one of your players that's getting a running start) the other team is allowed to cross the line and start playing defense.

As mentioned above, there is no physical contact with other players but you can use the ball however you want. If you're in the process of taking your 3 steps you can plow people over with the ball. If someone is charging you, you can kick the ball at them, you can hit people with the ball...I just prefer you don't aim for the head.

If you do actually blatantly contact someone you get a warning and a 2 minute penalty. Second offense in the same game gets you ejected from the game. This only happened once in 2 years of playing as the ball does a good enough job of not getting players TOO close to each other...

The ball is built like an exercise ball but it's VERY heavy. I would strongly advise players not try to punch the ball while it's in the air, hit it with one arm or kick it with your feet as it could easily result in an injury or twisting of the body. On that note, it's easiest to "kick" the ball with your knees or thigh, hit it with two hands punching close together or hit with the forearms while hands are clenched at the fists.

We sometimes have players get into a "scrum" around the ball and it doesn't move for a while. If that happens and the ball doesn't move for 3 - 5 seconds we'll have a jump ball from where the "scrum" took place.

Games are normally played until 11 and we switch sides of the field when one team scores 6. We usually take a little half-time break at that point too.

We have had many girls play the sport and they loved it. They were mostly lacrosse, rugby and soccer players though. A few of them even had trouble picking the ball up but they still loved the game. Some of them were actually our most die-hard players.

We normally start every game kicking and throwing the ball in a circle to get everyone warmed up for how big and heavy the ball actually is

The game is actually the most fun in the rain because of our most important rule...

NO CLEATS OR SPIKES OF ANY KIND! All players must wear tennis shoes or some other kind of non-grip shoe so they don't have any advantage in the dirt or grass. That's the way we've always played and I feel that makes everyone very even when it comes to maneuverability on the field. You can only imagine what some rain, puddles and slick grass add to a game where no one has traction. Good times.

Join us on Thursday, June 18th at 6:30 pm at Flagstaff Hill in Oakland for the first game of Big Ball.  Just show up to the park to play and bring some friends.  Don't forget the number one rule...No SPIKES!

This is a comedy/horror made right here in Pittsburgh! We can meet at the theater around 7:15. Show starts at 7:30 pm. For those that want to grab some food before, mention it in the chat. Here is the info about the movie: Bigfoot has come to the town of Ellwood City, PA and is causing BIG problems. Now it’s up to three town locals to take him down.

Funded by a Kickstarter campaign and filmed in Ellwood City, LA Filmmaker and hometown hero Jared Show assembled a colorful cast of characters from all over the region to bring his vision to life! The movie features some of Pittsburgh’s most famous and best loved celebrities like Curt Wootton (Pittsburgh Dad), Joanie Dodds (America’s Next Top Model), Jim Krenn (stand-up comic, formerly of the WDVE morning show), Mike Wysocki (WDVE), and even veteran news anchor Darieth Chisolm (formerly of WPXI) among others.

This comedy/horror flick that doesn’t take the Bigfoot legend all too seriously. Mullets, guns and beer are in full supply as the movie skewers the Pittsburgh ‘Yinzer’ stereotype right alongside the Bigfoot myth. This is a send-up that will delight anyone who has ever said or heard the phrase, “Hey, yinz goin’ dahntahn to pump an Iron ‘n at?”

results.description:
Please join us for the 5th Annual Pittsburgh JazzLive International Festival, presented by The Pittsburgh Cultural Trust on three outdoor stages Downtown June 19-21.

This free festival -- now in its 5th year -- has become one of our region's finest and most anticipated events as nationally and internationally recognized jazz musicians travel to Pittsburgh for a one-of-a-kind experience with performances on 3 outdoor stages along with local jazz musicians in celebration of Pittsburgh's rich jazz tradition.  The free festival consists of three days of jazz and jazz-influenced musical performances and attracts more than 20,000 attendees from around the country.

This is one weekend you won't want to miss featuring a number of Grammy-winning and Grammy-nominated musicians!

Check out these great articles about this year's festival http://triblive.com/aande/music/8442512-74/june-music-festival#axzz3dLv2pvXd

http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/music/2015/06/18/Rachelle-Ferrell-and-Ginger-Baker-headline-Pittsburgh-JazzLive-International-Festival/stories/201506180025

For more information (history, photos, videos, jazz links, etc.) about the Pittsburgh JazzLive International Festival (PJLIF) which also includes a nice JazzLive sampler to listen to music by past performers, please visit the official PJLIF website http://pittsburghjazzlive.com 

Once the complete schedule is announced during the Spring, we'll organize some specific Meetup events to check out free concerts and other performances. 

We'll also have the option of getting some street food quickly or dining in nearby restaurants (depending on the interests of the group)

We've also scheduled a Meetup event for Sunday June 21 afternoon and evening (which will feature 5 Great Jazz, Latin, & Calypso Bands plus Average White Band) and here are all the details if you'd like to RSVP for June 21 http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/events/223170141/</a>

With so many activities going on simultaneously each day during the festival, we've also added a Discussion Board forum for those that may wish to suggest some activities on a less formal basis. Please visit <a href="http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/messages/boards/thread/49034894">http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/messages/boards/thread/49034894

Because people will be arriving and leaving at different times, we'll incorporate some flexibility with some suggested possible gathering times/locations for the Meetup members to gather if desired.

As always, it is also fine if you'd like to attend this festival on your own with family/friends instead.

In the meantime, check out this great article about last year's festival http://triblive.com/aande/music/6252901-74/says-festival-locke#axzz35CLXD0VC

Stay tuned for updates!

Parking Here is the ParkPGH website with real-time info on downtown parking garage availability http://parkpgh.org  where you can also download apps, get garage availability via text messaging, etc. You can also call[masked]-8980.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet near Penn Avenue Stages I & II (near corner of 9th and Penn, outside Nicky's Thai, Nine on Nine, Sharp Edge restaurants)
results.name: Pittsburgh JazzLive International Festival (PJLIF) during June 19-21 -- FREE

results.description:
(This event was originally scheduled for June 12. The date has been changed to the 19th because of the Jeep Festival occurring on June 12-14 in Butler.)

The Northway Community Church holds a car cruise every Friday during the summer from 5:30-9:30 pm. (Note: although this is sponsored by a church, there is no overtly-religious content about the event.)

The church is located off Route 19 north of Wexford. Going north, turn left at the light at the Village at Pines shopping center across from the Giant Eagle. The large church will be on your right. Signs will direct you to parking. You are not supposed to park in the shopping center lot.

Meet at the main entrance at the front of the church between 6:15-6:30 pm. If you arrive later, look for those carrying photo equipment amongst the vehicles on display in the church parking lot. If you arrive earlier, take some photos, then meet us at 6:30.

I suggest taking bottled water with you. I also carry a notebook to record makes, models, and years. If vehicles have signs, I just snap a photo, but most do not.

At 8:00, meet at Bonnie and Clyde's (in the Village at Pines) for dinner, just across from the church.

Food booths are available at the car cruise, a coffee bar is inside the church, bottled water is for sale by church members, and other restaurants are nearby.

Rest rooms are available in the church.

No charge. (A donation is suggested if you want to display a vehicle.)

Rain date: June 26th.  If weather is iffy on the 19th, check this announcement before heading out to see if it has been rescheduled for the 26th.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the church's main entrance between 6:15 and 6:30.

results.description:
Skaters,

Please join us on Friday this week, June 19th for Gail & Dave's Wine & Cheese Skate. 

After the Friday evening skate please stay and socialize with your fellow skaters. Bring your favorite wine to share, cheese, or any snack food or beverage. If you don't drink wine, bring whatever beverage you enjoy and of course, all the skaters will enjoy other items besides cheese. It's a social, so be ready for conversation!!!  Even if you are not skateing please come for the party!!!

The skate time is 6:30, the social begins at 8:45. You are welcome to bring a guest.  We will meet at the Eliza Furnace Trail parking lot at the Greenfield end.  It is the same location as the Friday night skate.  Cheers!

Chris Croyle

Regular season Friday downtown weekly organized street and trail skate.

Intermediate skaters, helmet and wrist guards required at a minimum for our safety. 2+ hours skating of downtown, S.Side, North Shore, Strip District and other venues around downtown.  Trails, streets, bridges, stadiums, tunnels, Market Square, Station Square and more! See you there for a great tour of the city from the skaters perspective! And get a great workout.

Moderate pace. Urban skate. 10 to 16 miles. Mostly flat type terrain, but some gentler hills and sloped bridge decks and ramps may be encountered. Be able to maneuver in pedestrian and vehicular traffic, negotiate curbs, potholes, speed bumps and other urban amenities. Be able to brake confidently. This is a patrolled skate.

It is suggested that you wear light colored clothes, carry a flashlight, or wear blinkies, or reflective items.  Part of the skate will be completed as darkness is approaching.

Be ready to roll by 6:30 PM. Get there a little early to gear up and get ready to skate!

Frequent tailgate gatherings in the parking lot meeting place after the skate. And other post skate BBQ's, wine tastings, and other gatherings as the season progresses.

Come out and be part of the fun!

Cyclists are welcome to join us! Bike with us to enjoy an evening tour of the city. Also if you have not skated this meetup, biking is a good way to check it out.

NOTE: All skates are weather permitting. If it is dry we should be skating.

results.description:
The heroine of Kristin Gore's bestselling inside-the-beltway romp Sammy's Hill returns, and this time the laughs are richer and the stakes are higher -- at home and in the house (the White House, that is)Samantha Joyce is many things: Health care policy wonk. Hypochondriac. Lover of Japanese Fighting Fish (and of Charlie Lawton, her Washington Post reporter boyfriend). Jumper-to-conclusions. And when all these identities collide -- as they do most days -- the results are always unpredictable.

Sammy's role as an advisor to Vice President Robert Gary (RG for short) has led her down some exciting professional paths, like when she accompanies RG on a trip to India to help open pharmaceutical supply lines, and some troubling ones -- like when the president secretly asks her to plumb those lines to acquire as yet unapproved drugs for his own personal use. Her job interferes with her love life, too, after Charlie is transferred to New York for a huge story just when she's expecting a proposal, and they find that distance combines poorly with Sammy's dedication to her work and her overactive imagination. And then there's the surprising -- though ego-pleasing -- series of passes thrown Sammy's way, culminating in a highly embarrassing photo of a Hollywood hotshot's hand where it doesnt belong, published in the pages of Us Weekly . . .

As the dual crises in Sammy's personal and professional lives come to a head, and her ideals are put to the ultimate test, readers will be flipping pages madly, wondering what might come next. Because in Sammy's house, anything is possible.
results.how_to_find_us: Ask for the Chick Lit Book Club
results.name: Sewickley/Moon Meetup: Sammy's House by Kristen Gore

group.name: The Pittsburgh Chick Lit Book Club

results.description:
SummerSounds is a free series of exciting and interesting concerts under the stars in Greensburg's downtown St. Clair Park. Emphasizing high standards of contemporary musicianship in a family atmosphere, this series has been called "the best outdoor music series in Western PA."

This year's 13 free concerts will delight music lovers of all ages with music ranging from jazz to rock to bluegrass, with a taste of folk, new age and country. We're proud of the variety in our programs and try to please the most sophisticated ear. If the music makes you feel like dancing on the lawn, all the better! Dine at one of our fine restaurants or pack a dinner if you wish ... then stretch out on your blanket or lawn chair and enjoy the tunes. Best of all the price is right: FREE! And so is our parking! We want you to have a great evening in our downtown cultural district!

"Bands such as Fleet Foxes, Shovels and Rope, and Mumford & Sons are at the vanguard of a revival of a musical form running back through Fairport Convention and Steeleye Span.

The Last Bison, from the backwaters of Great Dismal Swamp in Chesapeake, Virginia (VA just happens to be the title of their latest recording), are ready to join that pastoral movement to the musical mainstream.

The very nature of their instruments (acoustic guitar, mandolin, banjo, violin, cello, pump organ), the essence of their lyrics, and the force of their performances, are all imbued with this pastoral sensibility. A good number of their songs start softly and slowly, and build on their acoustic nature into a swell of organic functions, and often, into a crescendo of choral voices singing simple messages layered upon ever more complex levels of melody.

Ben Hardesty, the main piece and singer-songwriter extraordinaire, brings his expressive voice to join with sounds produced by his father, Dan, sister, Annah Housworth, brother-in-law, Amos Housworth, and good friends and neighbors Andrew Benfante and Teresa Totherou. The string section of Teresa (violin, not fiddle) and Amos (cello, upright bass) are particularly evocative of the pastoral ideal. Nestled amongst our lawn and towering trees should be the perfect setting for this eclectic, creative, and transcendent group."

Pre-show music by Emay

 I am unable to commit to hosting and  attending every Friday, but I'm confident the group can utilize the comment section in order to organize the event. Due to the nature of this event, please feel free to invite your friends and significant other. The more, the merrier!!!
results.name: SummerSounds - The Last Bison

results.description:
In addition to limiting government's power, the framers of the U.S. Constitution implemented the Checks and Balance system to ensure that no one branch of the federal government could get out of control. As long as at least one branch of government kept it's primary goal as liberty, it could stop encroachments on the freedom of the people by the other two branches.

But what would happen if all three branches of the federal government changed their agendas from freedom to power and coercion? The vast majority of American citizens are unaware that the framers, who understood that a law is only as good as it's enforced, implemented a check and balance for such a situation as well. Fortunately, our system of government gives the power to the County Sheriff to either ignore or enforce Federal law. Neither the President of the United States, the U.S. Congress nor the U.S. Supreme Court can tell the County Sheriff what to do in his or her own county.

The County Sheriff is elected by the people, not employed by any branch of the government. Because he/she takes an oath to uphold the Constitution for the United States, his/her loyalty is towards protecting freedom. He/she decides which laws are Constitutional and will be enforced and which laws violate his/her constituents' rights and will be ignored. For the choices he/she makes, he/she will answer directly to the residents of his county, not the federal government. Ultimately, the County Sheriff is the check to balance any overreaching authority of the federal government, and is thus the last line of protection against any and all intrusive actions and legislation.

The Sheriff Project is designed to educate resident volunteers as to what they may rightly expect from their County Sheriff and how to determine if their Sheriff is fulfilling his/her oath to the U.S. Constitution. If the Sheriff is not, the residents, as the Sheriff Project, develop an action plan to either cultivate a relationship with their Sheriff or remove him/her from office. They stand with their Sheriff and do everything possible to aid him/her in defending their freedoms and promoting peace, security and constitutional law within the boundaries of their county.

For more information, see:
Local Sheriffs Are The Last Defense
The Sheriff - More Power than the President

This will be an interactive learning session in which we will go through building a database backed Rails 4 web application from almost scratch. The app will be a twitter like application where users can sign up for accounts, leave messages on other user's profiles, and view a feed of their current messages.

This presentation is directed towards anyone interested in learning rails! You do not have to have extensive programming experience to participate! However you should be familiar with some basic web conepts

Experience Requirements


- Basic understanding of HTML (know some basic tags and how they work)

- Experience using ANY programming language

If you have never done any programming or if you have never used ruby and want a head start on this class I would highly advise that you go through the intro to ruby tutorial on Codecademy


http://www.codecademy.com/en/tracks/ruby


Tech Requirements

- A wifi capable computer

If this is your first time building a web application I also recommend that you watch this video which explains some fundamentals of how web requests work

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e4S8zfLdLgQ


there will also be a link to part 2 of that video if you are interested in continuing learning

Hope to see you there!

-Andrew

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 10:00 at the tennis court of Moon park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

Bring a picnic basket, tea, and a large container/bag to hold the blossoms you pick. Come have fun outdoors. The linden tree blossoms once a year, producing fragrant flowers that make a lovely tisane that is believed to have health benefits. Warning: date may be subject to change if the linden trees blossom early or late.


We are going to meet at 10 am in the parking lot of Bob O'Connor Golf Course in Schenley Park (Oakland/Squirrel Hill area) for introductions and a little talk about Linden Trees, how to pick them,  and how to preserve/store them for the winter months.

Then we will go to harvest Linden Flowers ( I found today some great trees to the North of the clubhouse parallel to Northumberland Street - hope they will be just in perfect bloom by June 20:)

Watch this great video showing Linden flowers picking by Susan Weed:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qvLc4SyljDk

Schenley Park Linden trees behind golf course building 

Golf course parking lot, where we are going to meet (near the birdhouse).

results.description:
Welcome to another monthly meeting of the Pittsburgh Christian Apologetics Club. This time we will be looking at the topic of "Free Will". 

Here are some questions we will be thinking about:

• Why Did God Create Adam and Eve if He Knew They Would Sin?


• Will We Have Free Will in Heaven?


• Is God Sovereign or Does Man Have Free Will?


• How Did Evil Arise in a Good Universe?


• Why Does a Good Creature Choose Evil?


• Is the Human Mind Like Computer Software?


And other questions related to free will. 

Please watch this short video to get an idea of what we will be talking and thinking about

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0O8ACe92jww

What will we do?

We will watch a few videos related to the problem of free will from the Christian and Atheist perspectives, and then discuss the videos and the topic. 

Preparation materials: Please look at the notes for the meeting. I will give everyone a copy on Saturday. 

http://files.meetup.com/16204522/Pittsburgh%20Christian%20Apologetics%20Group%20meeting%2011.pdf

Important: Please follow the rules on this website during the meeting

http://ukranians2.wix.com/pgh-apologetics-club#!meetup-group/cwzz


We had some problems during the last meeting because people failed to follow the rules. People got offended. Remember, these are challenging topics. Why don't you discuss religion and politics at the dinner table? Because it causes WW3 among your family members. This is a club where we discuss those topics and try to be civil about it. 

People have different opinions, and the only way we will get anywhere is if we respect each other and give each other a fair hearing, and DO NOT talk over someone else while they are speaking.

results.description:
Pizza, hotdogs, cinnamon buns and more....

Gluten free, vegan, unprocessed (some raw) and with no refined sugar......yes, it's possible.

A part of the monthly Saturday Superfood Brunch series, this is a one-of-a-kind slow food event that typically runs for 3 hours, allowing guests to eat mindfully, socialize, network, have intellectual conversations, get informed about healing superfood ingredients and enjoy themselves while the food comes out course after course. By eating mindfully and not loading up on empty calories and carbs, guests leave more than full, nourished and satisfied. Table manners will be expected and very appreciated. Note: the date of this brunch has been moved to the third Saturday as the second Saturday is scheduled for the soft opening of extraVEGANza Pgh.

Milestones:

http://vstw.net/2015/04/an-evolution-of-eating/

http://www.muddymelissa.com/2015/04/12/review-zest-wishes-vegan-brunch/

http://pittsburgh.cityvoter.com/best/brunch/great-meals/pittsburgh

http://www.post-gazette.com/life/munch/2014/08/28/Munch-goes-to-Schwartz-Living-Market/stories/201408280139

http://www.wonderaddo.com/index.php/family-friendly-vegan-brunch/

http://muddymelissa.blogspot.com/2014/01/vegan-brunch-featuring-chef-mya-zeronis.html?spref=fb

http://www.pittsburghmagazine-digital.com/pittsburghmagazine/january_2014/?pg=104&pm=1&u1=friend#pg104

http://www.post-gazette.com/life/recipes/2013/09/19/Food-Column-Cook-and-learn-at-pop-up-dinner/stories/201309190282

http://www.popcitymedia.com/features/creativedinners0918.aspx

Enjoy a-whole-new-level vegan brunch items crafted by Chef Mya Zeronis of Lean Chef en Route/extraVEGANza, using GMO-free, local, organic ingredients and NO refined sugar, gluten, factory-produced, processed, packaged, textured mock meats, vegetable protein isolates TVPs and packaged, processed vegan cheeses.

Chef Mya Zeronis hails from meat-centric, butter-drowned, flour-covered U.S. restaurant kitchens but identified a need for healthful foods in Pittsburgh, Pa. and made it her business in 2013. Her business aims to make healthy eating and sustainable living accessible. Nearly a dozen of her recipes won top prizes in national and local contests. Some others were published in magazines and cookbooks. She never attended a culinary school. Cooking comes to her naturally.

[4 BEVERAGES]
Juice counter for make-your-own raw fresh juice blends:
Orange Glow organic carrots, Mandarin oranges, pineapples, ginger
Beet Me Up watermelon, berries, beets, cayenne

Chilled organic house-brewed, loose-leaf green tea with lemon
Organic, fair-trade coffee with homemade organic rolled oat-banana milk and grade B dark organic maple syrup

[10 DISHES]
This is a 3-hour-long slow food event that allows guests to eat mindfully, socialize, network, have conversations and enjoy themselves while the food comes out course after course. By eating mindfully and not loading up on empty calories and carbs, guests go home more than full, nourished and satisfied. Table manners expected.

1)Raw pizza with flax-oat-sunflower seed crust, spinach-cashew pesto, sliced tomatoes, basil, pea shoots
2)Mixed baby greens with chopped walnuts, raw apple cider-maple vinaigrette, apples, red onions
3)Scrambled cauliflower-chick pea eggs with coconut milk, turmeric, nutritional yeast, scallions
4)Carrot hotdogs marinated with sesame oil. apple cider vinegar, non GMO-project-verified light tamari. Served with millet buns and toppings: pickled watermelon rinds, pickled beets, homemade Sriracha, sauerkraut, grainy mustard
5)Asian-inspired, house sriracha-spiced black bean chili with, peppers, scallions, tamari
6)Homemade sprouted tofu-oat chorizo and potato hash with red onions, avocado oil, multi-color peppers
7)Chilled raw avocado-cucumber soup with walnut cream, cumin, cilantro, extra virgin olive oil, lemon
8)Quinoa-brown rice pasta, pine nut parmesan, tomato bell pepper basil sauce, parsley, Wild Purveyors portobello steak
9)Raw cinnamon buns with pecans, flax, dates, raisins, coconut butter, maple
10)Naturally-sweet blueberry-banana-coconut ice cream

Raw fresh ingredients are washed three times using baking soda-sea salt-filtered water solution.

Up to two children age 7 or younger, accompanied by paying adult, eat free. For each additional child or those 8-14, the cost is $10 and it's donated to No Kid Hungry.

This is reservation-only event and guests must pay in advance. Cutoff is two days prior to event. Want to get this brunch and upcoming brunches for $15 each? Sign up for a one-year Born To Brunch membership.

RSVP link: http://june20brunch.brownpapertickets.com/

GlobalPittsburgh is excited to announce its first International Barbecue and we are inviting you to join us. Each ticket purchased is a chance to win 2 round-trip airline tickets to any destination served by Delta in Europe or North America!

Our International Barbecue will bring together people who enjoy trying new foods from around the world with the people and cultures who prepare them. The event will recognize and celebrate the diverse cultures in the Pittsburgh region.

BUY TICKETS NOW!

Attendees will be able to choose from a wide selection of food from different cultures. Entertainment will be provided by DJ Pandemic and Global Beats Pittsburgh and a photo booth by DGM Photography. There will be activities for children including face painting and balloon animals.

The winner of the Delta tickets will be drawn at 3:30 PM. You do not need to be present to win. We're only selling a limited number of tickets, so get yours today! Early bird rates are available before June 1:
GlobalPittsburgh member - $30
Non-member - $40
Children 5-12 - $10

results.description:
FREEDOM SUMMER

Saturday, 6/20 - 2:00 PM
Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh – Homewood
7101 Hamilton Ave., 15208
Doors Open: 5 PM Suggested Donation: $2
Refreshments Available

“I’m going down to Mississippi
I’m going down a Southern road
And if you never see me again
Remember that I had to go”
Going Down to Mississippi by Phil Ochs

FREEDOM SUMMER
Written, Produced and Directed by Stanley Nelson
Country: USA Year: 2014 Genre: Documentary
Length: 120 Minutes
Website: http://firelightmedia.tv/project/freedom-summer/
Official Trailer:

http://vimeo.com/83539844

Synopsis (Courtesy of Firelight Media)
In the hot and deadly summer of 1964, the nation’s eyes were riveted on Mississippi. Over ten memorable weeks known as Freedom Summer, more than 700 student volunteers joined with organizers and local African Americans in an historic effort to shatter the foundations of white supremacy in Mississippi, the nation’s most segregated state. The summer was marked by sustained and deadly violence, including the notorious murders of three civil rights workers, countless beatings, the burning of thirty-five churches, and the bombing of seventy homes and community centers. In the face of this violence, these organizers, volunteers, and Mississippians worked together to canvass for voter registration, create Freedom Schools, and establish an alternative challenge to the State Democratic Party — the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party. Borne of Freedom Summer, and in response to the challenges of registering voters directly within hostile Mississippi, the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party registered its own voters outside of the discriminatory system, ultimately sending a delegation of 68 members to attend the 1964 Democratic National Convention in Atlantic City to confront and unseat the all-white delegation.
results.name: FREEDOM SUMMER Tells of the Deadly Summer in 1964 to Secure Voting Rights

results.description:
Do you enjoy using White Sage smudge sticks to clear your space of stale or negative energy?

Mugwort (Artemisia vulgaris) works much in the same realm. She has been said to have special reserved protective energies for women, but I feel that anyone who treats her with deep love and respect will reap hers in return.

Join me on the evening of Summer Solstice, to bask in the longer hours of daylight, and work with the highest energies of Mugwort.  Her abilities to assist us in higher levels of awareness and consciousness while in the dream state are shown to be at their peak during the Summer Solstice, when she, like us, receives the most sun (and in her case, photosynthesis.)  There is no better time to harvest her than this weekend!

We will discuss the history and uses of the plant,  sustainably harvest some of the plant for ourselves, and either wrap them into bundles to take home and dry for later use, or save them for our dream pillows!

I will provide some scissors / shears and twine for bundling-- you can bring your own, if you prefer, but I will have some for everyone to use.
results.name: Summer Solstice Mugwort Smudge Stick and Dream Pillow-Making Workshop

IT"S TIME TO BRING SALSA TO NEW HEIGHTS IN THE PITTSBURGH DANCE COMMUNITY!!

Join Salsa412 for a spectacular night of workshops and social dancing with one of the most dynamic salsa dancers from the Big Apple... Charlie Garcia, aka "Mr. Candela"!!

Charlie Garcia was born and raised in the Bronx, New York where he was exposed to dance at the age of 8 when enrolled into the Bronx Dance Theater. After trying his hand at basketball, chess and many other sports, Charlie began dancing again at the age of 14 at Unified Dance Company. At Unified, not only did he fall in love with dancing, but also with Latin music, most importantly Salsa. Since then, he's trained in salsa under many instructors and choreographers including Duplessey Monic Walker, Sonia Rivera, Anya Katsevman and more. 


In most recent years, Charlie has been pursuing a Salsa career and has since been under the direction of Marino la Rumba and Franklin Diaz. He enjoys taking classes with Sekou McMiller, coaching from Benito Garcia and training in other dance styles under various instructors. He currently directs Creative Movement Latin Dance Project and is striving to bring something unique and "fresh" to the salsa community.

results.description:
E Pluribus Unum. This phrase found on United States currency means “from many, one.” This phrase aptly describes the parish life in Braddock and the surrounding communities.

While the growth of industry and the rise of population in Braddock in the nineteenth century led to the creation of the many ethnic parishes, the loss industry and the decline of population in the area after World War II and the remainder of the twentieth century led to their suppression.  In 1982, the Edgar Thompson Works of U. S. Steel closed, causing a major loss of income and people to the area.  Beginning in 1983, the diocese conducted a study of the situation in Braddock.  The study determined that all six (later seven) parishes in Braddock should be merged to form a new parish. This happened in 1985 and Good Shepherd parish was created.

The worship site of the Good Shepherd Parish is the former Saint Michael the Archangel Lithuanian Catholic Church. Please join your Pittsburgh Mass Mob friends as we attend Mass and offer our support and right hand of fellowship to this body of believers who have been through so many changes.  God is gracious and has held together his flock here in the Good Shepherd Parish in Braddock, Pennsylvania!

A tour will follow the Mass at this lovely House of God.
results.how_to_find_us: We have reserved pews in the front center section of the church.
results.name: PITTSBURGH MASS MOB XI

results.description:
E Pluribus Unum. This phrase found on United States currency means “from many, one.” But this phrase also aptly describes the parish life in Braddock as well as the resilience of the surrounding communities.

While the growth of industry and the rise of population in Braddock in the nineteenth century led to the creation of the many ethnic parishes, the loss of industry and economic hardship during the latter half of the twentieth century took a heavy toll. With such huge declines in the once thriving Braddock population, The Catholic Diocese of Pittsburgh had a study of this very difficult situation which determined that six parishes -- St. Brendan (Irish), St. Isidore (Lithuanian), St. Joseph (German), St. Mary of Mount Carmel (Italian), St. Michael (Slovak), and St. Thomas (Irish) -- be merged to form a new parish and thus, Good Shepherd Parish was created in 1985.

The worship site of the Good Shepherd Parish is the former Saint Michael Catholic Church which was completed in 1930 after the original St. Michael Church in Braddock [masked]) had to be replaced. Of historical note is that St. Michael was the first Slovak parish in the diocese.


In case anyone might be interested, please feel to join the Pittsburgh Mass Mob friends as we rediscover another one of Pittsburgh's hidden jewels, another neighborhood church. Join us as we attend Mass and offer our support and right hand of fellowship to this community who have been through so many changes.

Please note that there will be a tour of the church immediately following Mass (which is usually less than an hour long)

As a reminder, it is important to recognize that while everyone may have different religious beliefs, we should also try to be respectful and welcoming, and realize that we can sometimes have a tendency to overlook historical things in our own region. 

As always, it is also fine if you wish to attend on your own with family/friends instead. 

Pittsburgh Mass Mob is a group that enjoys going to different churches which have historical significance in terms of architecture, rich ethnic/cultural tradition, etc.  Of note is that their are similar Mass Mob groups all across the country where visitors are struck by what they experience with comments such as “It’s like walking back in history.” 

Also Noteworthy -- with this visit to Braddock

1) Braddock is the setting for the famous novel "Out of This Furnace" by Thomas Bell -- and the local theatre company Unseam'd Shakespeare is presenting a new stage adaptation of  "Out of This Furnace" during June 4-21. Other Meetup events have been scheduled to check out this remarkable play which brings to life three generations of immigrant families living and working in the steel mills of Braddock, shedding light on labor issues and the rise of unions which are important aspects of both our region's and country's history (and also based upon Thomas Bell's own family of Rusyn and Slovak immigrants).  For more details about the play "Out of This Furnace" and the Meetup discount code, please visit  http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/events/220427692/

And if you wanted to see the "Out of This Furnace" play on Sunday, June 21 at 2 PM -- there would certainly be plenty of time to go to church (which is located very close to the Edgar Thomson Steel Plant), have lunch, and then see the play. 

2) Interestingly in 2013, there was a big movie "Out of the Furnace" filmed in Braddock starring Christian Bale, Casey Affleck, Woody Harrelson, Forest Whitaker, Willem Dafoe, Zoe Saldana and Sam Shepard http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Out_of_the_Furnace but this film is a different story which is NOT based on the Thomas Bell novel "Out of This Furnace" or the play.


3) However, during the last 10 years, Braddock has undergone revitalization, in part sparked by the arts, entrepreneurship, and strong community leadership. A new theatre, new restaurants, green energy businesses, housing initiatives, and other recent developments (such as Brew Gentlemen Microbrewery http://www.brewgentlemen.com which recently celebrated its one year anniversary) are making a difference in Braddock. So visitors may wish to check out some other establishments after mass.

And if you can't make it on June 21, please feel free to check out one of their other mass services during weekdays or weekends http://www.goodshepherdbraddock.org/

For more information about the history of Braddock, please visit http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braddock,_Pennsylvania

For more information about the history of Good Shepard Parish (and also the original ethnic churches in Braddock), please visit http://www.goodshepherdbraddock.org/parish-history.html

For more information about Good Shepherd Parish, please visit http://www.goodshepherdbraddock.org/
results.name: Pittsburgh Mass Mob XI at Good Shepherd Church in Braddock

Hi All,

We're meeting at 09:30AM at the tennis court of Schenley park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

We'll explore the lake for an hour or so then enjoy food & beverage on the lakeside patio at the OTB Cafe.

results.description:
Note: Your organizer (anu) is unable to plan a May Meetup, but feel free to propose one and it can be shared with the 100+ members of this group!

In June, let's talk about a really well-reviewed and apparently fun mystery, with some great suspense:

When Buck Schatz, senior citizen and retired Memphis cop, learns that an old adversary may have escaped Germany with a fortune in stolen gold, Buck decides to hunt down the fugitive and claim the loot. But a lot of people want a piece of the stolen treasure, and Buck's investigation quickly attracts unfriendly attention from a very motley (and murderous) crew in Daniel Friedman's Don't Ever Get Old, nominated for an Edgar Award for Best First Novel.
results.name: "Don't Ever Get Old" by Daniel Friedman

results.description:
VOTED as 1 of 10 TOP THINGS TO DO IN PITTSBURGH by the Pittsburgh Magazine!

http://www.pittsburghmagazine.com/Pittsburgh-Magazine/April-2012/Top-10/

About Italiano-Espresso©:

Italiano-Espresso was created with the idea of having weekly conversation get-togethers for all Italophiles to meet, practice and/or learn something Italian or in Italian.

Each week, there is one suggested/scheduled activity that will engage all speakers (from beginners to advanced and natives) in a fun and welcoming atmophere.

Spontaneous conversation is also welcome.

For those looking for a more structured learning environment, come and join us on Tuesdays (beginners) or Thursdays (intermediate) for Italian class (6:45pm/Wilkins School Community Center).

Italiano-Espresso is mainly held in coffeshops (i.e. the name "Italiano Espresso) and the location is chosen by the attendees on a monthly bases.

So, com'on out if you'd like to see us bring ITALIANO-ESPRESSO in your neck of the woods.

 

BIG NEWS: we have a BLOG!


 

 

 

 

The blog of Italiano Espresso is now online!

Wanna know more about our meetings? Check here the funniest topics we mention every Sunday: http://mondoitaliano.tumblr.com/

results.description:
Pittsburgh is hosting its first Make Music Day!  

Steel City Ukuleles is invited to play and will head up the ‘Burgh’s part in a nationwide "Mass Ukulele Event." 

We join Austin, Seattle, NYC, Santa Fe, Portland and 15 other cities.  More info at:  http://makemusicday.org

Where: Under the big white tent in Schenley Plaza in Oakland. Across from the Cathedral of Learning and Carnegie Library. 


When: June 21, Summer Solstice 2015

Time: 1 pm until TBA

Who: All SCU members, all levels, invited to play and sing.

Who else: ANY AND ALL local ukesters who would like to join.  

RSVP: To this Mother of all Meet-ups in the usual way. Fun and fame.

Music: BRING YOUR 365!!!  Most of what we'll be playing is from this book, but not necessarily in this order. :-)

This Land is Your Land, 234          I Walk the Line, 138              Country Roads (Blue, ?)                Rocky Top, 199                      Cindy, 55                                           Five Foot Two, 82                         You Are My Sunshine, 279            Oh, Suzanna 178                   Rocky Top, 199                                 Red River Valley, 195            Sloop John B, 214                            Hello, Mary Lou (Blue,134)        Side By Side, 210                             Stand By Me, 219                        All I Have To Do Is Dream, 18       Bye, Bye Love 41                    Happy Together, 98                        Hound Dog, 111                           I'm A Believer, 123                           King of the Road, 143                Let It Be, 146                                     Love Potion #9, 155              Under The Boardwalk, 245            Love Me Do, 154

Files You'll Need from the Website (or check spiral gig book if you have one)

Rye Whiskey                                    Lazy John                              


Sadie Green                                      Stealin'

Bottle of Wine                                  I Can See Clearly Now

Sail Away Ladies                               Bye-Bye My Roseanna


If you can't make this locale, we encourage you to play whenever and wherever you can on June 21.... a local shop, church or park, even your front porch!  If you register under the "Participate" section of the Make Music website, the national organization will add you to their schedule.

"Make Music is a free celebration of music around the world on June 21st. Launched in 1982 in France as the Fête de la Musique, it is now held on the same day in more than 700 cities in 120 countries. Completely different from a typical music festival, Make Music is open to anyone who wants to take part. Every kind of musician — young and old, amateur and professional, of every musical persuasion — pours onto streets, parks, plazas, and porches to share their music with friends, neighbors, and strangers. All of it is free and open to the public."
results.how_to_find_us: We will be under the large white performance tent across from CATHEDRAL OF LEARNING
results.name: Make Music Pittsburgh, June 21

results.description:
Please sign up if you're planning on playing and bring your favorite games!  Newbies are very welcome.  We have some great teachers to help you get started on your gaming adventure.  Let us know when you sign up what game(s) you'll be bringing.  On Sundays there is plenty of free parking on the side streets and even right on Murray.  Crazy Mocha serves great coffee, specialty drinks, snacks and pastries.  They do allow us to bring food in if we take our trash with us. We usually play all day, break for dinner around 6:00, then it's back to gaming until everybody poops out. 

Incidentally, many of our regular players no longer bother to sign up (but I really wish they would!), so if it looks like only  one or two people are coming, there could actually be quite a few more.  Remember, I will always cancel a game Meetup if we aren't gaming that day, so you won't be sitting there all by yourself waiting for a friend.    And please, remember to change your rsvp to no if you can't make it that day!

$1.00 will be charged to help cover the fee Meetup charges and to buy games for the group.  Join us and let the games begin!!!
