results.description:
Please join us for the 5th Annual Pittsburgh JazzLive International Festival, presented by The Pittsburgh Cultural Trust on three outdoor stages Downtown June 19-21.

This free festival -- now in its 5th year -- has become one of our region's finest and most anticipated events as nationally and internationally recognized jazz musicians travel to Pittsburgh for a one-of-a-kind experience with performances on 3 outdoor stages along with local jazz musicians in celebration of Pittsburgh's rich jazz tradition.  The free festival consists of three days of jazz and jazz-influenced musical performances and attracts more than 20,000 attendees from around the country.

Check out the incredible line-up of bands for Sunday June 21 which also includes their official websites as well as some of the cultural influences of the band leader (while of course, other band members may be from other countries) to give the audience a sense of the dynamic, multi-cultural nature of the PJLIF festival!

  Camila Meza       2:00-2:45 pm  (from Chile)  http://camilameza.com/

  Bebel Gilberto      2:45-4:00 pm  (from Brazil) http://bebelgilberto.com/

  Christian McBride Trio  4:00-5:30 pm (from U.S.)  http://www.christianmcbride.com/

  Etienne Charles Calypso Review  5:30-6:30 pm (from Trinidad) http://www.etiennecharles.com

  Sammy Figueroa and his Latin Jazz Explosion 6:30-7:45 pm  (from U.S.) http://www.sammyfigueroa.com/

  Average White Band  7:45-9:15 pm (from Scotland)  http://www.averagewhiteband.com/

This is one afternoon and evening you won't want to miss featuring a number of Grammy-winning and Grammy-nominated musicians!

For more details on the June 21 schedule of PJLIF performers, please visit http://pittsburghjazzlive.com/events/june-21-2015/

For a summary description and more links to all of the bands performing during the 2015 PJLIF, please visit http://pittsburghjazzlive.com/artists/

For more information (history, photos, videos, jazz links, etc.) about the Pittsburgh JazzLive International Festival (PJLIF) which also includes a nice JazzLive sampler to listen to music by past performers as well as the current line-up of 2015 performers and all of the activities associated with the festival, please visit the official PJLIF website http://pittsburghjazzlive.com 

We'll also have the option of getting some street food quickly or dining in nearby restaurants (depending on the interests of the group)

Because people will be arriving and leaving at different times, we'll incorporate some flexibility with some suggested possible gathering times/locations for the Meetup members to gather if desired.

As always, it is also fine if you'd like to attend this festival on your own with family/friends instead.

In the meantime, check out this great article about last year's festival http://triblive.com/aande/music/6252901-74/says-festival-locke#axzz35CLXD0VC

Stay tuned for updates!

Parking Here is the ParkPGH website with real-time info on downtown parking garage availability http://parkpgh.org  where you can also download apps, get garage availability via text messaging, etc. You can also call[masked]-8980.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet near Penn Avenue Stages I & II (near corner of 9th and Penn, outside Nicky's Thai, Nine on Nine, Sharp Edge restaurants)
results.name: PJLIF -- 5 Great Jazz, Latin, & Calypso Bands plus Average White Band (FREE)

results.description:
Tickets

A Comedy written by John Patrick

Directed by Larry Spinnenweber

In Special arrangement with the Dramatist Play Services

THE STORY: Mrs. Savage has been left ten million dollars by her husband and wants to make the best use of it, in spite of the efforts of her grown-up stepchildren to get their hands on it. These latter, knowing that the widow's wealth is now in negotiable securities, and seeing they cannot get hold of it, commit her to a "sanatorium" hoping to "bring her to her senses." But Mrs. Savage is determined to establish a fund to help others realize their hopes and dreams. In the sanatorium she meets various social misfits, men and women who just cannot adjust themselves to life, people who need the help Mrs. Savage can provide

Doors: 6:30 PM

Curtain: 7:00 PM

This show is B.Y.O.B. for our patrons 21

Light concessions will be available.
results.name: Curious Savage

results.description:
2 Rules for the meet up:

1) No solicitation of services *cool if someone comes to you but consultants/lawyers/coaches beware, any sales pitches and you'll have to find a new Monday ritual

2) Make sure to state whether what you are saying is an opinion or fact (both very much welcome) so to not confuse anyone about where the point of view comes from

Location change: Repair The World - 6022 Broad St. (Around the corner from Zeke's Coffee - grab your coffee from there and head over)

Share or listen to ideas but don't be fooled this is not startup therapy or feeding the ego this is about getting to work and removing the obstacles to make your idea a reality.

All entrepreneurs are welcome and it's not uncommon for us to have musicians, artists, chefs, writers, developers, renovators, or just about anyone else you can think of join the conversation.
results.name: Get your ideas or business UNSTUCK!

results.description: A Course in Miracles has been around for nearly 50 years, but its wisdom is timeless. And truly miraculous! This meetup, done with the flair of quantum physics as a guide, will dive deep into the text and process its soul-inspiring concepts, encouraging all participants to walk their pathway toward Truth. (Note: this is a heavily spiritual group with a strong emphasis on the presence of God in all of our lives ... we will use science as support for the concepts in the course, but the focus is primarily spiritual.)
results.name: Quantum Miracles: Charting Your Course (completed)

results.description:
Entrepreneurs helping each other. Bring your ideas, questions and experiences. Providing face-to-face help and feedback for your business in bite-sized chunks.

This meetup is right after the Unstuck Entrepreneur Meetup http://www.meetup.com/unstuckmondaymeetup/ which is right there at Repair the World from 8-9AM. Think about coming to BOTH!


After meeting outside in the lobby of Repair the World / Alpha Lab Gear / Thrill Mill, we adjourn upstairs to Alpha Lab Gear.

If you’re attending, check-in on the Sunday conference Call, RSVP here, let me know at another meetup or email me at [masked] so we’re sure to gather everyone.

This meetup is run by an experienced entrepreneur who started a business, ran it for over 20 years and successfully exited to a public company. He now keeps busy mentoring for a nationally recognized accelerator, reviewing business plans/pitches for investors and consulting for businesses & non-profits. When asked “why do a meetup?” he says he is looking to “pay it forward” by helping people make less mistakes than he made.
results.name: Discuss your startup ideas and help other entrepreneurs

We are being offered free use of the meeting room, and are therefore guests.  The Children's Institute has asked that we not park in their lot (handicapped members excepted; if you have plates or a placard, you can park in the lot), but park on the street.  There is parking on Shady Avenue.  The main entrance is on Shady.  You must register with the reception desk.  We meet in Room 220, which can be difficult to find if you've not been there before, so it is best to arrive early so the intrepid, experienced members who already know the way can lead you.  Bringing breadcrumbs is optional, but be aware that they clean and polish the floors in the evenings, and this is even more effective than birds for removing trails of breadcrumbs.  If you arrive late for your first meeting, ask the receptionist for directions.  Also be aware that anyone found wandering the halls muttering "220, 220..." after 9pm will be swept out with the trash.

results.description:
What will make Pittsburgh an accessible city for you?
Come to an interactive event to plan Pittsburgh’s capital budget – it’s a new, highly participatory process that should be fun and meaningful.
Pittsburgh's Capital Budget funds projects to build or renovate City assets such as bridges, roads, parks, and buildings. It also supports long-lasting programs to strengthen neighborhoods and improve quality of life. These public hearings allow Pittsburghers to voice opinions about where they feel City resources are best spent.
The hearings are open to everyone and officially hosted by the City of Pittsburgh. The Pittsburgh Accessibility Meetup encourages you to contact Gabe McMorland if you have difficulty requesting the city provide accomodations you need to participate. Gabe’s phone is[masked] and email is [masked]

You can register at the door, but the event hosts encourage you to register in advance by calling 412¬-255-¬4773 or by visiting
http://pittsburghpa.gov/omb/capitalbudget. (Walk-¬in registration will be


The City of Pittsburgh is hosting a Deliberative Forum
on the Capital Budget to provide a more robust way for residents to share
ideas on 2016 budget priorities. Modeled after the highly successful Police
Chief public meetings, these new forums will give neighbors a chance to
learn about the budget and add community voices to the budgeting process.
Forums are open to every resident of Pittsburgh.

*Each session will include:*

● a brief overview of the budgeting process,

● small ¬group discussions of budget priorities and residents' needs

● an opportunity for residents to ask questions of an expert panel
results.name: Make Accessibility a priority in Pittsburgh’s budget!

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 7:30 at the tennis court of Schenley park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

results.description:
Join us on Tuesdays for American Mah Jong! Folks begin arriving around 6PM, and we begin playing each table as soon as we have three or four players plus a set.  (We usually have 3-5 tables.)  We rotate among the tables... at the end of each game, East walks around to see if another table is close to the end of their game, so that two players can swap places. 


If you have never played, or if you have not played for a very long time, we highly recommend that you take a Mah Jong 101 beginner class before playing with us - beginner classes are offered every few months.  Mah jong is a wonderful game, but it's hard to learn by just watching others play!


Please order your 2015 card from the National Mah Jongg League, here: http://www.nationalmahjonggleague.org/ Amazon.com also carries the cards. Note that you want the NMJL card, and no other! (There are some colorful alternatives out there.. but we play NMJL card and rules.)

Experienced players -- please bring your cards and please bring a set if you have one.

Please do not bring any outside food or beverages into Panera! Instead, please plan to buy *something* from Panera, even if it's just a beverage or a cookie, to support their willingness to host us.
results.how_to_find_us: Hard to miss us, look for the Mah Jong sets!

results.description:
Beginner ukulele players in the South Hills of Pittsburgh. Now  you can jam with other newer players at Mt. Lebanon Library the 2nd and 4th Tuesday of each month. 

These sessions are for players who have had a few lessons or know some basic chords and want to learn more while playing with others. We will experiment with basic strums, alternate chords and how to move from one chord to the next. We will play songs slowly at first and then again, only faster. 

The group will choose the songs they want to play using "The Daily Ukulele 365 Songs for Better Living," by Liz and Jim Beloff. This book is available from local music stores and online. 

Bring your ukulele and a floor music stand along with the music book. If you want to play songs other than what is in this book, please notify the group the week prior so copies can be made. 

As we progress, we will open the group to more advanced players and more challenging music selections. 

If you have any questions, please contact Patty Williams at [masked].

results.description:
If you're into music, and even if you're not, here's a great opportunity to share any music you're interested in, have a cup of coffee or tea, and engage in conversation. We'll meet at Coffee Tree Roasters in Shadyside to chat, drink coffee, and listen to music. Bring your favorite music on your phone or thumb drive to share -- you can even bring an instrument to play if you'd like. And you can just come for the coffee and company – you absolutely aren't required to bring music (I will bring my laptop to look things up on YouTube as well).

Bring any music -- if you have music of your own creation, if you're passionate about a particular musician or band, or if you just like something and feel like sharing. It could be a recent find or something that influenced your childhood and got you though your teenage years. It could be something you love or it could even be something you hate -- just tell us why. Music is as much a story as anything -- it could be a story of you, or the story of the artist who created the music, or the story could be embedded in the song itself waiting for us to listen. Feel free to bring a story to share along with the music -- or not, if you prefer.

We're totally open to any kind of music so, please, bring anything you'd like to share be it classical, ethnic, heavy metal, or whatever -- even classical ethnic heavy metal (I bet it exists). We'll be meeting at Coffee Tree Roasters from 7pm (to probably 9pm though the room's booked until 10pm).

This event is also posted on meetin.org.
results.how_to_find_us: Inside Coffee Tree at 7pm, head to the glass-walled meeting room in the back.
results.name: Coffee Loves Music

results.description: It is perhaps Albert Einstein's most stunning insight: "Reality is an illusion, albeit a very persistent one." What did he mean by that? Here are two definitions of an illusion - "something that deceives by producing a false or misleading impression of reality" and "a thing that is or is likely to be wrongly perceived or interpreted by the senses." Precisely! The reason why the smartest scientist ever stated that we misperceive reality was hopefully made somewhat understandable throughout the first 11 levels. Now we shall conceptualize putting it into action, making the "illusion" concept work for you. It is truly the art of learning mind over matter.

results.description:
Featuring Drew Boyd, co-author of Inside the Box: A Proven System of Creativity for Breakthrough Results and Executive Director of the Master of Science in Marketing Program and Assistant Professor of Marketing and Innovation at the University of Cincinnati.


About the program

Surprisingly, innovation follows a set of patterns. For thousands of years, innovators used five simple patterns in their inventions, often without realizing it. These patterns are now embedded into the products and services you see around you. Think of them as the DNA of a product or service. An innovation method called Systematic Inventive Thinking (SIT) allows you to extract that DNA and apply it to anything you want to innovate – on demand.

The five patterns have been formed into structured techniques that regulate thinking and manage the ideation process. The method works by taking a product or service and breaking it into components. Using one of the techniques – subtraction, task unification, multiplication, division or attribute dependency –  innovators can manipulate the components to create new-to-the-world ideas. The method literally forces you to create combinations and configurations that you were not likely to come up with on your own.

Systematic Inventive Thinking is used successfully around the world in virtually every sector, public and private. Companies such as GE, P&G, J&J, and Kraft have applied the method to create new products, processes, services, and business models.

Registration will open soon! http://www.pdma.org/index.php?mo=cm&op=ld&fid=283 

Presenter Biography

Drew Boyd is co-author of Inside the Box: A Proven System of Creativity for Breakthrough Results. He is a recognized authority, thought leader, educator, and practitioner in the fields of innovation, persuasion, and social media. He is the Executive Director of the Master of Science in Marketing Program and Assistant Professor of Marketing and Innovation at the University of Cincinnati.

Boyd spent seventeen years with Johnson & Johnson in marketing, mergers & acquisitions, and international development. He founded and directed J&J’s acclaimed Marketing Mastery Program, an internal “marketing university” benchmarked by companies such as GE, P&G, Kraft, and Merck. Boyd’s focus was on raising competencies in the areas of strategic marketing, market management, and new product innovation. Of particular focus was teaching employees how to systematically invent new medical products and integrate the inventions into long-range strategic plans. Boyd is an inventor himself, earning his first patent for a device that makes spine surgery easier.

Before Johnson & Johnson, Boyd spent ten years with United Airlines, in sales, marketing, and strategic planning. Boyd was one of the early pioneers of strategic partnerships between carriers that led to the creation of the Star Alliance.

Boyd served as an officer in the United States Air Force and completed a distinguished tour of duty as a crew commander in the Nuclear Missile Force and a war planning officer of the Strategic Air Command. He was top Minuteman III Crew Commander in the “Top Gun” competition in 1980.

Boyd graduated from the United States Air Force Academy in 1976 with a Bachelors of Science Degree in Management Science and Operations Research. He earned an MBA from the University of Chicago.

He resides in Cincinnati, Ohio, with his wife, Wendy, and son, Ryan.

For more on Drew Boyd, visit his website: http://www.innovationinpractice.com/ ;
results.name: Innovation Inside the Box

results.description:
META MESH is building a wireless mesh network in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

What is a mesh network? Most of us have a home Internet connection to an Internet Service Provider (ISP) such as Verizon or Comcast. To communicate with each other, all our network traffic must go through these ISPs — even if the person to whom we are sending an e-mail lives across the street. This centralized way of networking presents many security and privacy problems.

A mesh network cuts out that centralized middleman. Instead of traffic having to go to a big server hundreds of miles away, a mesh network’s traffic is routed by the shortest and fastest possible path.

META MESH is building a network of wireless routers to make this model of networking a reality in the Pittsburgh area. That network is aptly named PittMesh. We don’t use expensive equipment to make this happen- in fact we’ve designed our network so that anyone can join it with consumer-grade, off-the-shelf Wi-Fi hardware available at any electronics store. When you join the PittMesh Network, you not only gain access to all the resources and anonymity that an “off-the-grid” network affords, but you expand the network, allowing others to connect and expand the network even further.

see

http://www.metamesh.org/


http://www.pittmesh.net/

results.description:
UPDATED:

How do we stop an out of control federal government?  Some people believe it is through an Article V Convention of the States.  This type of convention has been championed by Mark Levin and many others.

Still others are skeptical and are afraid of the possibility of a runaway convention which could forever change the current Bill of Rights, specifically, the First and Second Amendments.

So what are the answers?  What is the truth?  Just what would and wouldn’t be covered in an Article V Convention?

Are you against it?  Are you for it?  Have you even heard of it?

If you’re like me, you’re skeptical and have many, many questions.

If so, come on out to VPU’s monthly meeting for June where our guest speaker will be Mr. Steve Davies, the Pennsylvania State Director for the Convention of the States project.  He will be there to tell us exactly what an Article V Convention of the States would and would not cover and he’s prepared for questions and answers.

UPDATE:  Mr. Kim Stolfer, President of Firearms Owners Against Crime (F.O.A.C.) and strong Constitutional advocate will also be there to debate the other side of this issue.  (This should be interesting . . . )

And knowing our group, it should be a lively discussion with many great and interesting questions for both of the gentlemen, so bring a friend and introduce them to the group!


In addition to Mr. Davies, we will also be hearing from Ms. Natalie Mihalek, a Navy Veteran interested in running for the PA State Senate.

And, of course, we will also have our Federal, State, and Local Updates as always.

Hope to see you there!

In liberty, 

VPU Executive Council

P.S.  You can help us spread the word about this event by emailing this announcement to your like-minded friends.  And if you’re on Facebook, you can find us here:

https://www.facebook.com/groups/236434798671/
results.name: VPU’s Monthly Meeting for June 2015 – Article V Convention of the States

I've been to this a couple of times it's fun... Frank the Admin


The Pittsburgh Banjo Club is a non-profit organization made up of men and women from all walks of life, with a common goal - the encouragement and preservation of the banjo, America’s Native Instrument. Founded on December 15, 1988, by Frank Rossi, the Pittsburgh Banjo Club is dedicated to keeping the music of the Golden Age of the Banjo alive [masked]). Frank Rossi was inducted into the National Four-String Banjo Hall of Fame on May 24, 2001. The Banjo Hall of Fame is located at the American Banjo Museum in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.

The Pittsburgh Banjo Club includes banjos, trumpets, tubas, and bass. Dressed in bright, colorful uniforms, the Pittsburgh Banjo Club makes a striking appearance while playing the happiest music in the world, putting a smile on your face, a tap in your toe and a song in your heart! The happiest sound in the world is a banjo and the Pittsburgh Banjo Club provides miles of smiles!

The Pittsburgh Banjo Club program consists of sing-alongs, vocals, banjo solos, music from the ’20s and ’30s, polkas and Dixieland.

results.description:
How does a PittsburghTennisLeague Season / League run?
The league advertises the season dates and builds a queue of committed players for the season.

Kickoff Day - June 25th

The start day of the season, players are sent a kickoff email that contains important information about the league, the link where your league standings and players contact information. We guarantee 6 playing partners at your playing level, but have been averaging closer to 15+ partners in most cities.


Your Task - "Flexible Scheduling"
After this kickoff email is sent, it is the player's task to communicate with other players. Players should work with their partners to find an agreeable time and location to play the match. While PittsburghTennisLeague doesn't mandate your playing schedule, it is recommended that players schedule at least one match per week. By request of the players, we started to allow players to play 1 rematch per season. The regular season is all about playing as much as you can. As of Jan. 1st, 2013 we've had 189 players play more than 20 matches in a season.

Where to Play?
Play at your local free tennis courts, tennis parks, condo courts or tennis clubs. The league strongly suggests that players jointly try to pick a tennis court location convenient to both. We provide an extensive list of tennis courts, including # of courts, lighting, hitting walls, etc. We strive to keep this list up-to-date

PittsburghTennisLeague sets up a must play dates to push players out on the courts. The final deadline is the date marking the end of the season, at which point players with 5 wins will qualify for a post-season playoff to determine the league champion.


How to Play?
Players can use three semi-standard playing formats: 2 out of 3 sets, 2 sets with 10 point super tie-breaker or the 10-game pro set (First to 10, used when court time is limited).


Playoffs
Each season concludes with a playoffs where players with anywhere from 3 to 5 season wins qualifies for a single elimination tourney. The champion is awarded based upon the league Prize Pool. Each singles league champion also receives a playing entry into the National Tourney which is already scheduled for Crandon Park Tennis Center in Key Biscayne - Nov. 13-15, 2015.


Join Today!!
Full price is $24.95 to play in a season, BUT the earlier you sign up we typically offer discounts during these tougher economic times. Just go to the Join Page and complete the short form. We'd be happy to find you dedicated tennis playing partners.
results.name: Summer Flex Season

I always liked comedy!  I Frank Will be getting there at 6 pm (starts at 5:30pm, i cannot make it that early) to enjoy some Wigle Whiskey cocktails and watch some comedy ($5 if buy tickets ahead of time, $8 at the door!)

Pittsburgh Comedy Festival: Open House at Wigle Whiskey Barrelhouse!

If you’re curious about exploring the city’s comedy scene, or an existing fan eager to show your support, this super-fun fundraising party is for you! Enjoy short sets from local improv and stand-up acts, join in grown-up-friendly games lead by City of Play, and indulge in fantastic cocktails from Wigle’s award-winning distillery. Hungry? No worries – there be food there!

The Comedy Open House will also feature a delightfully unconventional comedy raffle. Buy tickets throughout the evening for the chance to be featured in a comedian’s set, have a song made up about you on the spot, and much more.

City of Play is on board to stage some outdoor games!

Tickets are $5 online at (FREE & ALMOST FREE get your tickets ONLINE! save some CASH!)

http://pittsburghcomedyfestival.org/comedy-open-house/

and $8 at the door.

3 FOOD VENDORS:

MIDNIGHT MUNCHIES: GYROS, Custom Burgers, Luscious Mac N Cheese + a Vegetarian Menu.

Second Breakfast is bringing the irons so we can get our ‪#‎waffleon‬!

Pgh Crepes will be serving up the crepes that your heart desires!
results.how_to_find_us: I will be there at 5:30pm frank's contact for texting: 724-987-0784.  Make sure you buy your ticket ahead of time to save money ($5 instead of $8!).
results.name: Pittsburgh Comedy Festival: Open House at Wigle Whiskey!

Pittsburgh Comedy Festival: Open House at Wigle Whiskey Barrelhouse!

If you’re curious about exploring the city’s comedy scene, or an existing fan eager to show your support, this super-fun fundraising party is for you! Enjoy short sets from local improv and stand-up acts, join in grown-up-friendly games lead by City of Play, and indulge in fantastic cocktails from Wigle’s award-winning distillery. Hungry? No worries – there be food there!

The Comedy Open House will also feature a delightfully unconventional comedy raffle. Buy tickets throughout the evening for the chance to be featured in a comedian’s set, have a song made up about you on the spot, and much more.

City of Play is on board to stage some outdoor games!

And of course, a slew of PCF staff members and performers will be in attendance to answer questions about the festival, set you up with passes, and chat about all the amazing people, venues, and opportunities awaiting comedy-interested Pittsburghers.

A portion of the proceeds from the evening will be donated to Pittsburgh Comedy Festival, which is a project of the non-profit group Comedy Arts Pittsburgh. PCF and CAP aim to expose Pittsburgh to the art of comedy, raise awareness of the imaginative, innovative talent that exists in the city, and engage Pittsburghers of all ages in the growing comedy community.

Tickets are $5 online at

http://pittsburghcomedyfestival.org/comedy-open-house/

and $8 at the door.

results.description:
What: Oakmont Toastmasters Club Open House

Location: Oakmont Public Library 700 Allegheny River Blvd Oakmont, PA 15139

When: Thursday, June 25 Registration 6 p.m. Event 6:30 p.m.

Cost: Free

Contact: Amy Noll at [masked] (412)[masked]

The ability to communicate effectively is one of the most important skills you can develop. Businesses need people who are able to express themselves clearly and confidently. Whether you are informally communicating a proposal or making a formal presentation, the ability to communicate confidently and persuasively is essential to your success. Please join us at the Oakmont Toastmasters Club open house to see how Toastmasters can help you become a better communicator and more effective leader.

Note: The Oakmont Toastmasters club meets weekly at the Riverview Community Action Corporation (RCAC). All are welcome to attend any of the upcoming meetings. Please note that the open house on Thursday, June 25 will take place at the Oakmont Library. Location: RCAC 501 Second Street Oakmont, PA 15139 When: Every Thursday from 6:30 p.m. – 8:00 p.m.

results.description:
Come explore the Wildflower Reserve as we meander down the trails at a slower pace. Along the way, we will be guided by Shane Miller Park Educator, who specializes in botanical education. This walk will be less than 1 mile and focus on Blue Crayfish and Ferns found along Henrici Trail. Trail will include one hill going up and one hill going down with 200ft elevation change.

Time - 6:30pm to 7:30pm
Topic(s) - The top packages to use with Meteor projects and simple examples.

Getting started with Meteor is fairly straightforward and not much of a challenge. But, what do you do from there?

This meetup is designed to be an introduction to some of Meteor's most popular packages to integrate with your projects. As well as just showing you how to quickly implement packages to get your application up and running quickly.

Packages will include, but are not limited to:
- Accounts
- Iron Router
- Fast Render
- Velocity
- etc

Jazz (The Resumator) has kindly agreed to sponsor this meetup's pizza and soda.
results.name: Favorite Meteor Packages Overview & Socializing

results.description: “Christina Baker Kline is a relentless storyteller. Once she sets her hook and starts reeling you in, struggle becomes counterproductive. The narrative line is too taut, the angler at the other end too skillful.” — Richard Russo Between 1854 and 1929, so-called orphan trains ran regularly from the cities of the East Coast to the farmlands of the Midwest, carrying thousands of abandoned children whose fates would be determined by pure luck. Would they be adopted by a kind and loving family, or would they face a childhood and adolescence of hard labor and servitude? As a young Irish immigrant, Vivian Daly was one such child, sent by rail from New York City to an uncertain future a world away. Returning east later in life, Vivian leads a quiet, peaceful existence on the coast of Maine, the memories of her upbringing rendered a hazy blur. But in her attic, hidden in trunks, are vestiges of a turbulent past. Seventeen-year-old Molly Ayer knows that a community-service position helping an elderly widow clean out her attic is the only thing keeping her out of juvenile hall. But as Molly helps Vivian sort through her keepsakes and possessions, she discovers that she and Vivian aren’t as different as they appear. A Penobscot Indian who has spent her youth in and out of foster homes, Molly is also an outsider being raised by strangers, and she, too, has unanswered questions about the past. Moving between contemporary Maine and Depression-era Minnesota, Orphan Train is a powerful tale of upheaval and resilience, second chances, and unexpected friendship.
results.name: Book Club : Orphan Train by Christina Baker Kline

results.description: Shakespeare had it precisely correct ... and sounded strikingly similar to Jesus in the Gospel of Thomas when he said, "When you become two, what will you do?" To be or not to be? Be or not be what?!? We will answer that question in this group after we process what it means! The first 16 groups have led up to this point - the halfway point of the series - where we begin to gradually shift the focus away from the science of the material world and more toward the soul of the spiritual world.

results.description:
Regular season Friday downtown weekly organized street and trail skate.

Intermediate skaters, helmet and wrist guards required at a minimum for our safety. 2+ hours skating of downtown, S.Side, North Shore, Strip District and other venues around downtown.  Trails, streets, bridges, stadiums, tunnels, Market Square, Station Square and more! See you there for a great tour of the city from the skaters perspective! And get a great workout.

Moderate pace. Urban skate. 10 to 16 miles. Mostly flat type terrain, but some gentler hills and sloped bridge decks and ramps may be encountered. Be able to maneuver in pedestrian and vehicular traffic, negotiate curbs, potholes, speed bumps and other urban amenities. Be able to brake confidently. This is a patrolled skate.

It is suggested that you wear light colored clothes, carry a flashlight, or wear blinkies, or reflective items.  Part of the skate will be completed as darkness is approaching.

Be ready to roll by 6:30 PM. Get there a little early to gear up and get ready to skate!

Frequent tailgate gatherings in the parking lot meeting place after the skate. And other post skate BBQ's, wine tastings, and other gatherings as the season progresses.

Come out and be part of the fun!

Cyclists are welcome to join us! Bike with us to enjoy an evening tour of the city. Also if you have not skated this meetup, biking is a good way to check it out.

NOTE: All skates are weather permitting. If it is dry we should be skating.
results.how_to_find_us: Eliza Furnace (Jail)Trail access parking lot, off 2nd Ave. between the Hot Metal Bridge (28th St.) and the underpass to Greenfield / Hazelwood.  See the attached map if you need directions. "FREE" parking at the trail.
results.name: TRIC/NSP Friday Night City Sights - Weekly Street and Trail Skate

results.description:
Investigating Murder:  A Detective Walks Through a Case and Two Psychiatrists Analyze the Whys

In case anyone may be interested, there will be a fascinating discussion on police work, psychology, and murder.  

Included is discussion of the real-life case of Dr. Jeffrey Farkas (a promising pedriatics intern resident working at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh) who was murdered inside his Squirrel Hill home in 1989 -- as this same case was featured on the recent TV show "Ice Cold Killers: Dead of Winter (TV Episode 2015)" that was released in January 2015.  Here is a link with more information about the episode, including a preview video http://www.vudu.com/movies/#!overview/637442/Ice-Cold-Killers-Dead-of-Winter

While the focus of the upcoming June 26 discussion is certainly on helping people as well as preventing and solving crimes -- and a glimpse of the underlying criminology/psychology/psychiatry (and perhaps how forensics/understanding has changed during the last 25 years) -- this discussion may also be of interest to those that might appreciate a sense of the behind-the-scenes research that writers do for films, TV, books, plays, etc.

About the June 26 Program:

Ron Freeman, Dr. Robert Wettstein, and Dr. Howard Foster will participate in a discussion on police work, psychology, and murder.

Ron Freeman worked 38 years with the Pittsburgh Police, 19 years as a Homicide Detective, and 14 years as Commander of Homicide.  He will discuss the investigation of Dr. Jeffery Farkas' death and include examples of police use of psychology.


Following his presentation, Dr. Robert Wettstein and Dr. Howard Foster will share their thoughts on the connections between psychology and murder.

Robert Wettstein, M.D. is a Clinical Professor of psychiatry at the University of Pittsburgh and adult and forensic psychiatrist in private practice.  He has written and contributed to many articles, book chapters, and editorial pieces on psychiatry, criminology, and a variety of other topics. 

 Howard Foster, M.D., psychoanalyst and psychiatrist in private practice, spent time in the early '80s as a Psychiatric Consultant at Western Pennsylvania Correctional Institute and Allegheny County Behavior Clinic.  He also served as Director of the Mental Health and Forensic Psychiatry Unit at Allegheny County Jail, where he set up a mental health program.

TICKETS


While tickets are normally $25 General Public, $15 Students  -- there is a discount for the Meetup group courtesy of the Pittsburgh Psychoanalytic Center which is sponsoring the June 26 Discussion.

So Meetup members can save $10 -- and pay only $15 (the same rate as students) with the promo code culturalarts when they go online http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/1667945

For more information about the June 26 Discussion and other events sponsored by the Pittsburgh Psychoanalytic Center as part of their Continuing Education and Community Outreach programs, please visit  http://www.pghpsa.org/public-events-continuing-education/ 

For more information about the Pittsburgh Psychoanalytic Center including their history and many programs (including collaborations with arts organizations such as Quantum Theatre, Carnegie Library), please visit http://www.pghpsa.org/


For more information about the Pittsburgh Athletic Association (which can also accommodate a wide variety of other social and cultural events), please visit http://www.paaclub.com/Club/Scripts/Home/home.asp

Our plan for the rest of the year is something along the lines of meeting every other week and alternating between Friday and Saturday nights, so everyone has a chance to join us and play games.

Our new location is the recently opened White Rabbit. They have a wonderful space and are letting us take up tables for hours and they only ask that you bring a few dollars so you can buy a coffee or a pastisserie (fancy-speak for pastry). I can personally vouch that  the coffee is delicious!

results.description:
OUT OF THIS FURNACE ... Returns!

Based on Thomas Bell’s famous story of immigrant families living and working in the steel mills of Pittsburgh.

The triumphantly human story of heart sweat and steel. Your Story.

Three generations of the Kracha/Dobrecjak clan struggle to build a life in the shadow of Carnegie’s first mill. A dramatic adaptation of Thomas Bell’s intimate tale of immigrants, labor and the rise of unions in Braddock, PA.

*In a new adaptation*

Directed by Lisa Ann Goldsmith

June 4th - 27nd, 2015

About the Play

When Unseam'd originally premiered "Out of This Furnace" in 2008 at the former Open Stage Theatre (located in the Strip District), it quickly became one of the hottest tickets in town with many sold out performances.  Audiences loved the play which attracted many steel workers and their families along with others with personal connections to the steel mills as well as many audience members that had read Thomas Bell's iconic novel.  The 2008 production had a great cast, set, and soundscape making audiences feel the sounds inside the mills.  The 2008 play was adapted for the stage by Andy Wolk (based on Thomas Bell's iconic novel) and directed by Marci Woodruff. 

Due to popular demand, the play was restaged by Unseam'd in 2011 at a different location, which was the Studio Theatre in Oakland. This production was also directed by Marci Woodruff but had a different cast. The 2011 production also had a very successful run in terms of audience response.

And now, this 2015 production will be a new adaption directed by Lisa Ann Goldsmith with a new cast featuring Charles Beikert, Lea DiMarchi, Kate Falk, Matthew Mazurowski, Julia Netzer, Max Pavel, Charles David Richards, Jennifer Tober, Tammy Tsai, and Mark Warchol

Performances during June 4 - 27, 2015


Studio Theatre in the Cathedral of Learning

4200 Fifth Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213

GENERAL ADMISSION: $27 Advance ($30 at the door)
STUDENTS: $15 Advance ($18 at the door)
SENIORS: $22 Advanced ($25 at the door)
GROUP (6+): 10% Discount (Advanced Sales Only)

SHOWTIMES: Wednesday through Saturday @ 7:30 pm, Sundays @ 4:00 pm as well as Saturday June 27 matinee @ 3 PM


Post-show discussions with director and cast on Wednesday, June 10 & 17

MEETUP Ticket Discount

If anyone is interested in going to the June 4th - 6th shows, you can order advance tickets at the special price of $22 by entering MEETUP in the promo code box when checking out online. This code can only be used on general admission tickets for the June 4th - 6th shows. 

For all of the other performance dates June 7-27, a 10% off discount will be available by entering MEETUP10 in the promo box.

For advance tickets, please go online to the Unseam'd website http://unseamd.com/box-office/ or ShowClix website http://www.showclix.com/search/out%20of%20this%20furnace to see all of the performance dates and then you can enter either the promo code MEETUP for $22 online tickets for the June 4-6 performances or MEETUP10 code for 10% off online tickets for all of the other performances June 7-27.

You can also call ShowClix at[masked]-4253.

For more information about Unseam'd Shakespeare, please visit http://unseamd.com/

We'll also try to arrange some alternate dates for Meetup groups to check out this powerful thought-provoking play. So please post some comments below if you'd like to suggest some alternate performance dates for the group to consider. 

If anyone is interested in going with the Meetup group on Wednesday, June 17, there will also be a post-show discussion with the director and cast. I'm sure there will be some interesting questions and insights. To RSVP for Wednesday June 17, please visit


As always, it is also fine if people would like to go on their own with family/friends for a truly memorable evening.

Stay tuned for updates!

About the Novel Out of This Furnace (from Wikipedia)

Out of This Furnace is a historical novel and the best-known work of the American writer Thomas Bell. The novel is set in Braddock, Pennsylvania, a steel town just east of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania along the Monongahela River. It was first published in 1941 by Little, Brown and Company. Based upon Bell's own family of Rusyn and Slovak immigrants, the story follows three generations of a family, starting with their migration in 1881 from Austria-Hungary to the United States, and finishing with World War II. The novel focuses on the steelworkers' attempt to unionize from 1889, the first Homestead strike through the big Homestead Steel Strike of 1892, the Great Steel Strike of 1919 right after World War I, and the events of the 1930s (<a>Labor Organizing</a>). A common connection of struggle, poverty, and entire need of the characters of forces out of their control come together to tell a story of a tragic depiction of a truly troubled group of people. Shared with unbearable financial adversity, the Slovaks nicknamed "Hunkies" were also exposed to discrimination by other "Americans." The novel's title refers to the central role of the steel mill in the family's life and in the history of the Pittsburgh region.

Long out of print, the novel was rediscovered in the 1970s by David P. Demarest, a professor of English at Carnegie Mellon University, who convinced director Frederick A. Hetzel at the University of Pittsburgh Press to reissue it in 1976. The book quickly became a regional bestseller. By the 1980s, however, it found an even larger readership on American college campuses. Out of This Furnace is regularly used as required reading in universities to introduce students to the history of immigration, industrialization, and the rise of trade unionism, as well as to the genre of the American working class novel.

Join us for our June Lock and Key Singles Party! A great non-intimidating way to meet singles in the Pittsburgh area!

 

 

 

Lock and Key Events are the new, interactive and FUN way to network, meet your match, make new friends....or just to have a great time!

Details of our next Meet-up:

June 26th, 2015

Cavo Restaurant Lounge
1916 Smallman Street
Pittsburgh, PA

Suggested Age range: 24-47 (if you are a little older...no biggie!!)

Check-in: 6:30-7:00pm
Mix and Mingle: 7:00-9:00pm
Prize drawing at 8:45pm
Done at 9:00pm and then stay & party until closing with no cover!!

INCLUDES:
- 1 FREE DRINK w/ purchase of 1st Drink*, AND FREE APPETIZERS (until 8:00 PM),
- Free admission into Cavo Lounge (no additional cover if you stay afterwards)
- Great prizes, and the opportunity to massively mix, mingle, make new friends, and who knows what else!


How It Works
Every woman gets a padlock. Every man gets a key. Your goal is to match the right key with the right padlock. Every time you unlock you get a ticket that enters you into the drawing to win great prizes from our party sponsors. Prizes such as cold hard cash, hotel stays, dinners, tickets to popular things to do and more. After every unlock you get another lock or key so you can get back into the fray and meet more people!

Register at www.lockandkeyevents.com/PIT!! Use the code PITMEETUP to attend for ONLY $22. If you don't wish to prepay for this event, you can pay $27 CASH at the door IF you put in an RSVP. Otherwise, it's $32 at the door!!

PRIZES YOU CAN WIN!

Every time you unlock, you can win prizes such as:

One $75 CASH Prize! One $50 Gift Certificate for  Cavo Restaurant Lounge One - $50 Gift Certificate to The Melting Pot of Pittsburgh One - Gift Certificate for One - 30 minute Full Body Massage from Massage On The Go By Teesha ($40 value) 2 Personal Training Sessions with Jim from Integrated Fitness ($110 value each) Complimentary Admission tickets to Pre-Dating Speed Dating Events ($35 value each) Complimentary Admissions into future Lock And Key Events And more!
Please email or call me with any questions!!

See you there~
Casey

The day will feature a number of wargames where all figures, terrain, dice and everything else needed to play will be provided. If you would like to run a game there let me know. We will be gaming from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. So far we have a French and Indian War game, an American Civil War game, a 20th Century Dogfighting game and of course you can game on our interactive diorama of the Battle of Bushy Run. This is a great opportunity for people new to historical or miniature gaming to try out a bunch of games. Admission to the event also includes admission to the museum that day. We will have tour guides at the event to show people around the visitor's center and the battlefield. Food and beverage will be available for sale on site. All you need to do is show up and push some figures around the table top.

Admission is only $5 and all proceeds go to help keep Bushy Run Battlefield open.

results.description:
Please join PICT Classic Theatre for a very special breakfast and lively conversation about Irish literature and culture!

Choose from a menu of three traditional, delicious Irish breakfast food and discuss celtic folklore with PICT Artistic Director Alan Stanford and Aoife Spillane-Hinks, the acclaimed director of "Sharon's Grave" which will be PICT's next production during July 16 - August 1, 2015.

And this is a great opportunity to learn about this play and meet the creative forces behind bringing this play to life in Pittsburgh.

Of note is that Aoife Spillane-Hinks was also the director of PICT's production of the Samuel Beckett classic "Waiting for Godot" which the Post Gazette rated as the second best play during 2014 http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/theater-dance/2014/12/18/Best-Play-Tamara/stories/201412180110 while Alan Stanford designed the set and reprised his famous role of the character Pozzo which he has performed many times, including touring the world with Gate Theatre of Dublin (before Alan moved to Pittsburgh).

So sharing a brunch with Alan Stanford and Aoife Spillane-Hinks with their extensive experiences in Ireland (as well as fun knowledge of Irish literature and culture) represents a truly unique opportunity. And we can all be grateful to have a chance to meet Aoife Spillane-Hinks while she visits Pittsburgh as director of the upcoming "Sharon's Grave"  during July 16 - August 1, 2015.

For tickets ($25) for this very special breakfast, please visit https://picttheatre.secure.force.com/ticket/#sections_a0FU000000BEe6nMAD Please call PICT at[masked] with any questions

Get ready for"Sharon's Grave"  in true Irish fashion!

Please note there will be separate Meetup events that will be planned to see the play, such as on Thursday July 30 where there is a nice ticket discount and optional pre-show dinner discussion. For more details on the various ticket discounts or to RSVP for the July 30 performance of the play, please visit http://www.meetup.com/Art-lovers/events/223470253/

In the meantime, here is some background information about "Sharon's Grave"


About "Sharon's Grave"

Trouble is brewing as Donal Conlee takes to his deathbed. His lonely daughter must fight for her land and protect her brother against the scheming of their malignant cousin. This story of land-lust, mystery and folklore is a classic tale, set against the rugged North Atlantic coastline of Ireland in the 1920s. Witness the mastery of one of Ireland’s foremost storytellers and playwrights as he weaves the tale of this Conlee family feud together with the mythical story of a beautiful Celtic princess, Sharon, who meets an untimely end. Similar to the plays of Synge or McDonagh, this is a show for all the family to enjoy.

Performance Schedule

For more information about PICT Classic Theatre and this production, please visit www.picttheatre.org

For more information about Claddagh Irish Pub, please visit http://www.claddaghirishpubs.com/pittsburgh/

results.description:
We will be reading a good "beach read" It is Nancy Thayer's
Guest Cottage.

The New York Times bestselling author of Nantucket Sisters whisks readers away to the island of Nantucket in this delightful story about two single parents who accidentally rent the same house one sunny summer.

Wendy Anderson is 35, the mother of two children, and happily married―until she discovers her husband Zack has cheated on her. Confused, angry, and lost, she rents a house on Nantucket for two summer months. When she and her children arrive at Isle Stay, she discovers that Trevor Black, 30, recently widowed, and his son Dylan, 5, have also rented the house. Neither one is willing to give up their much-needed vacations, so Wendy and Trevor devise a plan to share the house for the summer. Preparing meals in their one kitchen, Wendy and Trevor become friends, and chemistry builds throughout the seabreezy summer. But the house is full of their children, and neither is sure they’re ready to move on after recent heartbreaks. Over the last sun-soaked weekend of the summer, as chaos reigns and emotions run as high as the temperatures, Wendy must decide where her heart truly lies.

Please join us, the book club meetings are such fun! If you don't have time to read the book - just come for the lunch and fun.

results.description:
THE HERO (O HERÓI)

Saturday, 6/27 - 2:00 PM
Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh – Homewood
7101 Hamilton Ave., 15208
Doors Open: 5 PM Suggested Donation: $2
Refreshments Available

REVIEW

"A 20-year veteran of the 30-year-old Angolan civil war finds assimilation into the chaotic life of the capital city of Luanda a challenge in this affecting drama. Gamboa shows an assured directorial hand by managing the multiple storylines with aplomb." - Variety The Hero (O Herói)

Director: Zézé Gamboa Screenwriter: Carla Baptista
Genre: Dramatic Feature Countries: Angola/Portugal/France Run Time: 97 min.

Trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oGucCn9Hcn8

Winner: World Cinema Jury Prize Dramatic
2005 Sundance Film Festival

Review

Ever since its 30-year civil war ended in April 2002, the country of Angola has been struggling to piece itself back together. Director Zézé Gamboa's beautifully crafted film the Hero is emblematic of this national effort. Indeed, its extraordinary level of accomplishment heralds a new era of Angolan cinema.
(Shari Frilot, Sundance Film Festival 2005)

Synopsis (Courtesy California Newsreel)

The Hero (O Herói) is the story of Angola, a nation torn apart by forty years of uninterrupted war, and now trying imperfectly but courageously to piece itself back together. It is also the story of a city, Luanda, like so many in the Third World, trying to absorb the millions of people displaced by civil strife and global economic change.
results.name: Angolan Film THE HERO Looks at the Aftermath of War on a Nation and its People

results.description:
WPLUG is the Western Pennsylvania Linux Users Group, based in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA. We are a not-for-profit organization that provides collaboration resources (including mailing lists and this very wiki), presentations, and installfests, for Linux users of all backgrounds.

Experienced Linux users are welcome; curious persons wanting to see what Linux is all about are welcome -- There are no requirements to join our lists. However, the discussions will be oriented to Linux and other Free and Open Source Software.

Most of our members are from the local area, but we do have list participants from far-flung locations.

WPLUG is ultimately governed by its membership, but the Board of Directors handles most day-to-day activities, with help from various committees.

You can contact us by e-mailing [masked],

See website: http://www.wplug.org/
results.name: Linux Meetup Group (WPLUG)

results.description:
Join us for a unique evening of FREE entertainment at the Carrie Furnaces.  Part Eco-Opera, part Broadway Cabaret from Opera Theater of Pittsburgh's SummerFest!


Enjoy delicious onsite food, soft drinks, craft beer (including Voodoo!), and retro cocktails available for purchase from Blue Dust Gastropub starting at 4:30 pm. Blue Dust will have their famous brisket sandwiches as well as vegetarian options and standard BBQ fare.

The new Eco-Opera, A New Kind of Fallout, is inspired by Rachel Carson—a pioneering woman scientist whose work was instrumental in founding the Green Movement in America. Two women artists were invited to write the opera—acclaimed local playwright Tammy Ryan the libretto, and Gilda Lyons the music. The results are thrilling, and Opera Theater of Pittsburgh would like to share sections of the work as it is created with audiences in a series of workshops. A New Kind of Fallout is the first in a series of commissions called 'Music that Matters,' envisaged as a series of new operas which will address critical issues we confront in our society today—hot button topics such as global warming, race relations, violence, etc. Opera is often viewed as something of a museum art form; this project aims to bring that notion up to date by creating new works that are relevant, provocative, and important to people today.

Free public workshops of the new Eco-Opera, A New Kind of Fallout, have been scheduled in venues that matter in terms of preservation of our eco-systems, including the Phipps Conservatory, the Pittsburgh Botanic Garden, Rachel Carson's alma mater Chatham University, Carrie Blast Furnace, and others. Each workshop will present new scenes from the opera—hot off the press—and explore the issues it raises in discussions with the artists.

These workshops will lead up to the mainstage world premiere production, which takes place as part of Opera Theater SummerFest 2015 in July at the Twentieth Century Club—one of the 'don't miss' cultural events of the year!

Performance starts at 6:00 pm.
Free if you bring your own chair or blanket! ($10 if you would like a chair provided)

Reserve a free ticket at http://otsummerfest.org/events/fallout-workshops Please note that they need an accurate count for food/drink planning please!

Free parking onsite. 

4-6 pm Optional ticketed tours (one-hour) of the Carrie Furnace site. Starting times are staggered. Watch for sign-up details. $10

More on Carrie Furnace site and directions:
http://www.riversofsteel.com/

For information, including musical excerpts you’ll be hearing from the upcoming SummerFest during July 10 – August 2, with operas, a musical, the world premiere of a newly-commissioned work, a global recital series, a children's opera, and more, please visit http://www.otsummerfest.org/ Please note that all operas are sung in English.
results.name: Eco-Opera, Cabaret & Cocktails at the Carrie Furnaces

Of course, the real prize is meeting a Potential Match!  Again, this fun Ice-Breaker is Totally Optional with the MIXING & MATCHING taking place from 8:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. during the regular DANCE WHICH WILL CONTINUE UNINTERRUPTED FROM 8:00 P.M. TO MIDNIGHT FOR OUR ENTIRE CROWD WITH MUSIC BY DJ George! Admission $8 with complimentary Snacks available on all of the tables to be enjoyed by our guests!  Check-In time for "A PERFECT PAIR" is from 7:30 p.m. to 8:00 p.m..  MIXING & MATCHING will take place during the dance from 8:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. with the RAFFLE PRIZE DRAWING for participants later in the evening!!!  Participation in this cool Ice-Breaker is totally optional and our Main Event, THE SATURDAY SINGLES DANCE, where singles gather to socialize, dance, and meet new people, will be held from 8:00 p.m. to Midnight as always!  RSVP TODAY to be a part of this novel, fun, ice-breaking event and to win exciting Giftcards and Prizes! FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THIS EVENT AND OUR DANCES: Call the Dance Line at[masked], email [masked], or visit the Dance Website at www.dancetonight.weebly.com

results.description:
Jam On Walnut is a great Festival!

Jam On Walnut, a benefit for the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, is a three day outdoor concert, occurring one Saturday during each summer month. Each of the three events attracts approximately 5,000 people for the city’s BEST BLOCK PARTY. The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation shuts down Walnut Street in Pittsburgh’s Shadyside Community at 6pm for a night of fun, food, drinks and Pittsburgh’s hottest bands.  $5 to get a wristband if you want to drink beer from the beer trailers on the street.  If not FREE!

2015 Bands and Dates:

June 27th- Donora/ Chris Higbee 

July 25- Bon Journey/Radio Tokyo

August 22nd- Kelsey Friday/Dancing Queen

The concerts start at 7:00 and ends at 11:00. Happy hour is from 7:00p.m.-8:30p.m.

  So get there early and help support the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation with a night of fun.

Meet Frank at Corner of Filbert & Walnut at 8pm.  I'll be cooking, but can BS and this is a great place to meet others from meetups to people watch, watch the great bands or just go to the Bars/Restaurants. 

I will spare some time at 8-8:10pm but then gotta get back to work ;-).
results.how_to_find_us: I will be cooking & serving food here, it's a great festival! Say hi!
results.name: Jam on Walnut! Amazing Multi-block party w/ 2 bands and thousands!

results.description:
EXPLORING THE PIANO: Duphly 300th Anniversary [masked])

Jacques Duphly [masked])

The French organist, and later turned harpsichordist, Jacques Duphly [masked]) was one of the cross-over composers of the Baroque period. His works contains elements of both the Baroque and Classical periods. This recital will feature beautiful and elegant selections from three books for harpsichord (performed on the piano) published between 1744 and 1756 the year Mozart was born.

results.description:
Join us for our weekly regular season Sunday Morning Social City Skate.

This Sunday will be a special skate as part of the OPEN STREETS Pittsburgh event. We will skate into downtown and join the Open Streets route at Market Square, Skate out Penn Ave. Thru the Strip District to Doughboy Square at Penn Ave. / Butler St. Then out Butler Street thru Lawrenceville to 47th St. The streets will be closed to traffic and open to all pedestrians, walkers, skaters, cyclists,families, etc... The route will be about 4 miles long from Downtown to L'ville. There will be activities, performance areas, food, sidewalk cafe's, entertainment, kids activities, and more. come out and skate or ride with us for this special event skate.

This is an intermediate level social skate of 10-15 mile, mostly flat route, with minor inclines at bridges, ramps and other similar areas. Enjoying the scenic views of the Southside, Strip District, downtown, Station Sq., Mexican War Streets and Northside.   An optional coffee stop is included near the end of the skate.

The intermediate skater should be comfortable skating in street traffic, braking on both flat and inclines and manueving curbs, pot holes, etc.    The steepest hills are the bridge decks and the 10-15 miles are at a relaxed paced.

This skate is a slightly more challenging then the Wednesday advanced beginner skate.

Skate will be led and patrolled by the National Skate Patrol.

Cyclists are welcome and encouraged to join. Also a good way to try the Sunday Skate route on your bike if you haven't skated it before.

Skate is weather permitting.  If it is dry we should be skating!
results.name: OPEN STREETS PITTSBURGH - Sunday Morning Social City Skate.  9:00am to 11:30am

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 09:00AM at the tennis court of Schenley park and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,

results.description:
Morning Update: The weather looks promising! Reminder if the concert is on we're meeting by the stage (look for my red and white IKEA umbrella and red blanket). If not, we're meeting at the Center for the Arts (see below). If you're confused text me at[masked]-0072.

Weather Update: If it's rainy and the concert looks like it won't happen, let's meet at 10:00AM in front of or in the lobby of the Pittsburgh Center for the Arts, the yellowish building at the corner of 5th and Shady Ave adjacent to Mellon Park. We can explore the gallery ($5 admission) or we can check out the free yART sale which promises to happen tomorrow rain or shine.

Here's more about the yART sale:

Pittsburgh Center for the Arts holds an annual "yART" sale – a creative spin on the traditional yard sale – on the lawn, every summer. Adjacent to Mellon Park, PCA's tree-lined campus is at the corner of Fifth and Shady in Shadyside. Admission is free; and hours are 10:00 – 4:00, rain or shine. 

The annual outdoor event features approximately 80 local artists. They are cleaning out their studios to bring affordable art, equipment and art supplies. Expect to find ceramic pieces, photographs, jewelry, art books, fabric, unframed prints, glass pieces, and collectibles.

It's a great opportunity for folks to get outside, meet local artists, and find a few art bargains. yART Sale prices range from 50 cents to 200 dollars, with most items at bargain-basement prices.

I haven't made it over to Bach, Beethoven, and Brunch in Mellon Park the last couple of years. It's a wonderful event but I always end up saying "maybe next week" and somehow the summer always passes too quickly. This time, I figured I'd post so I'd have to show up!

Bring your breakfast or brunch and we'll have a picnic outside listening to great music. Folks from the Bagel Factory will be there if you'd like to buy coffee/breakfast there. I'll meet you near the front of the stage at 10am. I'll email my phone number out the day before the event. The concert starts at 10:30am. Feel free to bring blankets and chairs and so on.

From Pittsburgh Parks:

This longtime favorite series entertains music lovers on the lawn at Mellon Park. Satisfy your appetite for classical music by treating yourself to a special Sunday morning composed of Bach, Beethoven and Brunch. Join us for this delightful buffet of classical melodies.

Don't miss the "Best Brunch" competition! The Pittsburgh Center for the Arts hosts a "Best Brunch" competition each week and will award prizes! Citiparks staff members judge the brunches based on presentation, effort and food selection - with the "Best Brunch" winner announced during intermission.

The group performing this week is the Quinta Voce Wind Quintet. Check out  their website for more info. This event is also posted on meetin.org.

Note that in case of inclement weather, call the concert hotline [masked]) to check if the event is cancelled.
results.how_to_find_us: At 10AM, on blankets in front of the stage. I'll email out my number the day before.

About Italiano-Espresso©:

Italiano-Espresso was created with the idea of having weekly conversation get-togethers for all Italophiles to meet, practice and/or learn something Italian or in Italian.

Each week, there is one suggested/scheduled activity that will engage all speakers (from beginners to advanced and natives) in a fun and welcoming atmophere.

Spontaneous conversation is also welcome.

For those looking for a more structured learning environment, come and join us on Tuesdays (beginners) or Thursdays (intermediate) for Italian class (6:45pm/Wilkins School Community Center).

Italiano-Espresso is mainly held in coffeshops (i.e. the name "Italiano Espresso) and the location is chosen by the attendees on a monthly bases.

So, com'on out if you'd like to see us bring ITALIANO-ESPRESSO in your neck of the woods.

 

BIG NEWS: we have a BLOG!

results.description:
This simple fable of a man seeking his destiny and fulfilling his dream from Brazilian author Paulo Coelho is an international best-seller, and its inspirational message has been called life-changing by many readers.

"Paulo Coelho's enchanting novel has inspired a devoted following around the world. This story, dazzling in its powerful simplicity and inspiring wisdom, is about an Andalusian shepherd boy named Santiago who travels from his homeland in Spain to the Egyptian desert in search of a treasure buried in the Pyramids. Along the way he meets a Gypsy woman, a man who calls himself king, and an alchemist, all of whom point Santiago in the direction of his quest. No one knows what the treasure is, or if Santiago will be able to surmount the obstacles along the way. But what starts out as a journey to find worldly goods turns into a discovery of the treasure found within. Lush, evocative, and deeply humane, the story of Santiago is an eternal testament to the transforming power of our dreams and the importance of listening to our hearts."
results.name: The Alchemist by Paulo Coelho

results.description:
Come out and dance in the Sunshine and be part of this incredible event and help Claire in her efforts to open Journey Forward Pittsburgh! 

Along with the sunshine and getting to meet Claire and hear her story, there will also be a Chinese Auction, a 50/50 raffle, and many other surprises, plus great music by The NIEDS HOTEL BAND, and DONNA  O. hosted by "the ANGELS"
Suggested donation is $10 and would be greatly appreciated

Claire's Story .........................
On May 9, 2006, Claire broke her neck in a gymnastics accident and suffered a spinal cord injury. She was paralyzed from the neck down. She could not feel or move her arms, hands, core, or legs. Initially she believed she would only be able to stabilize her neck through surgery to prevent further damage. Journey Forward changed Claire's life. Journey Forward is a 501(c)3 non profit organization dedicated to bettering lives of those with spinal cord injuries through an intense exercise based program. Journey Forward strives to give their clients the best opportunity at regaining sensation and function below the level of injury while increasing their overall quality of life. The closest Journey Forward is in Massachusetts.

We desperately need a Journey Forward in Pittsburgh. Not only do others deserve a chance at recovery, but they deserve a chance to feel hope, healthiness and encouragement, and to see their loved ones at eye level again. We all deserve a chance to increase our quality of life, and Claire has seen Journey Forward increase every single person's quality of life at their center, even the staff lives. It's time we gave Pittsburgh this same opportunity!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the meetup signs!
results.name: Charity Event:Dancing With Claire  at Fox Chapel Yacht Club

results.description:
featuring:

Mimi Jong, erhu & zhonghu

Tomchess, oud & ney

Ravi Padmanabha, tabla & percussion

Mimi Jong, a dear friend of World Kaleidoscope and champion of musical experiments and experiences, regularly performs on the erhu and zhonghu, Chinese two-string fiddles, with master musicians from many different cultures, such as India, Persia, Tuva, and Spain.  This concert showcases her collaboration with Tomchess and Dan Kurfirst, both of New York City.

Tomchess, one of the most fascinating oud players, is a multi-instrumentalist/improviser and composer who has played and recorded with some of the heaviest players in the improvisational scene. Having deeply studied the Near Eastern, and North African traditions, he has incorporated the tonal palette, rhythms, and forms of these traditional musics while never losing sight of his American roots and the importance and freedom of improvising.  His astonishing technique, combined with a poetic verve, conjures unpredictable musical delights.


Mimi and Tomchess will be accompanied by the master tabla player, percussionist, and multi-instrumentalist, improviser and composer Ravi Padmanabha, all of which will be sure to provide a melodic melding of Eastern folk styles and improvisational jazz: "an interesting, adventurous and intimate sound together with a near telepathic and fiery exchange."

results.description: Thanks to another suggestion from one of our members, we are reading Nick Harkaway's Angelmaker. Here's what the Guardian had to say about it: "Nick Harkaway is a hyphen-novelist. A tragical-comical-historical-pastoral novelist, if you like; or – more precisely in the case of this second book – a fantasy-gangster-espionage-romance novelist. The Gone-Away World, Harkaway's well-received debut, was a slightly overfilled post-apocalyptic pick-and-mix of genres. Just as blithe in its disregard of verisimilitude and generic constraint, Angelmaker flits between old-fashioned villains in London's East End and covert action in 1940s south Asia, arranging its whistlestop plot around the modern-day discovery of a weapon of mass destruction in the unlikely form of a skepful of clockwork bees. It's an ambitious, crowded, restless caper, cleverly told and utterly immune to precis." This is a lengthy novel. Please join us even if you don't finish the book :) Hope to see you there!
results.name: June Book Smoup: Angelmaker

results.description:
$35/player pricing - what a deal! Includes numbered shirt!!

We need guys to get another indie team going. You up for playing? 

Sign up as an individual - great way to meet new friends! - with a group of friends or as a full team.

Choose from one of the following: Men's 11v11 Monday only

What's included in the price?

• 7 weeks of regular season plus up to two weeks of playoffs
• 2 friendly and certified referees per game
• 11v11 
• Two 25-minute halves
• Championship t-shirts/trophies
• Food/Drink specials at sponsor bar
• We will not place more than 20 players on a roster. Most individual team rosters have 12-16 players.

Format
11v11 

When are we playing?
This league plays a round robin regular season with game times rotating from 7:00 on Mondays. A full season schedule<a></a> and standings will be available on sportsmonster.net by week 2.


Playing surface and what to wear:
We play<a></a> on a turf field. Shin Guards are mandatory in all league games.

Level of competition:
- Recreational level is ideal for teams just forming, teams with a mix of experienced and novice players and maybe teams that have lost a step or two over the years and are looking for a more relaxed environment.

These leagues are happening!
Don't see a bunch of people registered here? Don't worry! Many people and teams register<a></a> directly on our sportsmonster.net website instead. So go ahead and sign up to play!


Full Team Registration<a></a>
*Want to register as a Full Team? -- If you want to register a full team, you can do so but roster size MUST be at least 18. And yes, you can pay for all 18 here. If players are signing up on their own, have each player/group be sure to reference one another so we know to place you together -- see questions when you RSVP.


When will I find out which team I'm on?
When more than one option is offered, you MUST be flexible and provide a 2nd choice. Once a team is formed, a roster will be provided to all the players and we ask someone from the team to volunteer to act as captain to ensure a full team is showing up each week and a positive vibe is maintained throughout the season.

Don't have PayPal? You may register through Sportsmonster.net and pay by check or money order but you will be paying full value as presented on that site.

If you have any questions please don't hesitate to ask.
Call:[masked]
E-mail: ryan @ sportsmonster.net


All registrations made through this Meetup event agree to the terms and conditions found on sportsmonster.net.

results.description:
Please register for the June Pittsburgh SQL Server Users Group meeting here: http://june2015pssug.eventbrite.com/?aff=meetup


Featured Presentation: Dr. DMV's Troubleshooting Toolkit

Speaker: Glenn Berry, Principal Consultant SQLskills

Summary: Dynamic Management Views and functions allow you to easily see exactly what is happening inside your SQL Server instances and databases with a high level of detail. You can discover your top wait types, most CPU intensive stored procedures, find missing indexes, and identify unused indexes, to name just a few examples. This session presents, demonstrates and explains numerous DMV queries that you can quickly and easily use to detect and diagnose configuration and performance issues in your SQL Server instances and databases.

About Glenn: Glenn Berry works as a Principal Consultant at SQLskills in Parker, CO. He is a SQL Server MVP and has a whole collection of Microsoft certifications, including MCITP, MCDBA, MCSE, MCSD, MCAD, and MCTS, which proves that he likes to take tests. His expertise includes DMVs, high availability, hardware selection, and storage subsystems. Glenn is also an adjunct faculty member at University College - University of Denver, where has been teaching since 2000, and has completed the Master
results.name: Dr. DMV's Troubleshooting Toolkit

This meeting is sponsored by Experis.

Experis is the professional services division of Manpower and offer a full suite of IT professional resourcing and project services. We go to market with a local office sales and recruiting model that includes our 75+ offices in the U.S. , including our downtown Pittsburgh office located in the Federated Towers. In 2014, Experis was recognized as the 5th largest IT staffing firm in the U.S. by Staffing Industry Analysts (SIA) with 4% market share.  

A few areas of industry differentiation for Experis include:

-  Project Solution Services-  Experis has nine (9) core practice lines led by Sr. Directors/Solution Architects expert in their respective domain areas. Our practices provide support and coverage across Experis local offices and have the ability to co or fully manage a defined project delivered by our internal engagement teams. A few key practices include Development Solutions, Infrastructure and Data Solutions, Business Intelligence and Information Security.

-  Employee Based Consultant Model – we have invested tens of millions of dollars in the past two years in a program targeting the overseas hiring of in demand development skills. These resources are primarily qualified .Net and Java developers and are full time salaried bench employees of Experis. These consultants have been thoroughly qualified prior to hiring investment, will relocate across the United States for client engagements, and available to client’s at cost effective market rates including a performance guarantee.

Lastly, Experis is a Microsoft Gold Services Partner. In addition to having a critical mass of .Net consultants on staff, we have six development centers in the U.S. offering a full suite of .Net development services from custom application development, application migration from legacy to .NET technology, enhancements, and production support services.
